output: Mr. President, Madam Vice President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student scrambling to make up for lost time before submitting their paper.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered as a step towards the Commission taking social issues into account.

The President of the Commission failed to grasp the warning given by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These elections are a wake-up call.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not merely to adopt yet more technical directives.
Regulations concerning the internal market are certainly necessary, but they are not, and by far not, the essential element.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the mark.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to merely supplement, nor even simplify, legislation.
They expect the Commission to rise to the challenge assigned to it by the treaties, the engine, the think tank of the Union.
It is not enough for that its president be wise and silent at attention behind the President of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the society we need.
But what is the societal vision underpinning this program?
The 2009 program contains no major errors, but it is not the program that our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to assume its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Mr. President, first of all, a question to the Council.

the guide for the high-level conference on Georgia proposed by the French Presidency and how the current Presidency of the Union intends to defend Georgia's territorial integrity, while a country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
But it’s a pity that Mr. Barroso isn’t here because, in his speech, he wasn’t convincing, perhaps because he himself isn’t convinced by the proposals he has put forward to us.
I believe that the financial and economic situation is far more serious than he has led us to believe.
Even today, I believe that those who follow the internet can clearly see that stock markets continue to collapse despite interventions.

It truly, for me, represents the collapse of the current system, a system completely obsolete, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led a land to be totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that led to underdevelopment in the Global South and that led to underdevelopment in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, a global action is required.
And that is true, particularly in the fields of agriculture or food.
That is why, in particular, the World Trade Organization was created, on which we agree, which seeks to establish global rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like because we are facing a problem, which is as follows: we must reconcile two things—free trade, which is necessary and on which everyone agrees—but protections, which are equally necessary.
and the protections of national economies or agricultures, this does not mean protectionism.
The path we have taken for the past 60 years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced one, leading to the reduction of tariffs with the objective of their elimination.
It so happens that, technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is quite difficult, the proof, a whole series of mathematical formulas, the Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn’t really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with very different origins, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical deadlock, and politically, through negotiations, we are attempting to resolve it.
Alternatively, it happens that, technologically, a new customs technology has been invented: the technology of export duty refunds on the importing State's economy.
Concretely, this deductible customs duty transforms into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable, and eligible for bonus.
It is refundable at the moment when the exporter, upon purchasing from the importer, can deduct the customs duty they have borne.

It is negotiable because, if the exporting company that has borne one hundred percent in customs duties has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates without a customs credit on the stock market or with a bank.
It is eligible for bonus if we wish to assist developing countries, the importer, in offering a credit duty amount exceeding the duty amount.
Well, with this technique, we create an international currency of exchange whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency within the commercial sector.

Mr. President, the Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis provided the European Union with the opportunity to assert itself on the world stage as a fully-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
Faced with crises, Europe demonstrates its existence and proves its added value.
In the matter of immigration, for example, the every man for himself approach was no longer current.
The adoption by the European Council of the pact on immigration and asylum, initiated by the French presidency, represents a significant step forward.
Regarding the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete objectives and demonstrate leadership to its global partners.

You have already expressed your opinion on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very destabilized.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges that await them, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution at the December European Council; many of us are calling for it.
In recent weeks, we have observed with pride that a strong, united Europe, resolute in the face of adversity and determined in its dealings with partners, is being heard on the international stage.
We desire that this new European mindset become the norm and that it endure.
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution available to us for achieving this.
Madam President, Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan and, of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted swiftly and knowing how to stop that war.
But this war is, in a way, our failure. We were hesitant for fourteen years, we silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

This war, certainly, has awakened Europe by placing it before its responsibilities, but the fire continues to smolder in the Caucasus and we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I am also aware, Minister, of the divisions among European countries regarding Georgia’s accession to NATO, and personally, I am opposed.
I will put forward a proposal: I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasus countries.
Only the status of neutrality can alleviate tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this subregion from experiencing new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.

Mr. President, Minister, these past three days have seen the European Development Days, during which the food crisis affecting the poorest and most vulnerable countries has been extensively discussed.
All interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

Incidentally, the lyrical pronouncements of those who called yesterday and still call today for a reduction in state intervention and public spending, for the liberalization of all of Asia, for privatization, for the relegation of agriculture, are shifting.

This almost prehistoric activity, this volte-face therefore in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all of it had something both comical and scandalous about it.
The future of agriculture in developing countries has a direct relationship with the debate we are having today.

Regrettably, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the hunger riots and the disastrous market disturbances, takes into account the situation of farmers in the southern countries and draws all the consequences of the severe crises we are experiencing today – ecological, social, economic, and financial.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between farmers in the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission’s proposals and in the Parliament’s report, and the questioning of the promised one billion euros demonstrates how much further there is to go.
Mr. President, the report we will vote on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th of last year that Ms. Fischer Boel presented us with her proposals regarding the health assessment.
Following Lutz Goebbels’ interim report, here is Capula Santo’s report on the Commission’s proposal.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's agriculture committee managed to remain firm against the initial proposals from the Commission, which we considered far too liberal.
Madam President, I will remain vigilant regarding the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.

I am particularly thinking of mountain milk producers, who must not be the poor relations of this reform, and it will be essential to ensure that they are not left aside, as they will need to be more strongly supported than others.
I don't want to dramatize things, but how can one imagine the French dairy industry clustered within a single region?
Therefore, I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund with benevolence, as well as the proposal to evaluate, starting in 2010, the increase in milk quotas in accordance with market developments.

Mr. President, I believe the progressive modulation calculation performed by the Agriculture Committee to be fair and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rurality, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also commend the clarification of the eco-conditionality, the implementation of which had previously been a genuine challenge for farmers.

I also wish that we retain the tobacco fund amount, which allows us to maintain small farms in Europe, as well as a considerable workforce in a region where nothing else is exploitable and which allows us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated considerable patience and determination, and you have not spared your time, without fail.
It was a genuine pleasure to work alongside you.
You have been remarkably effective with us.
I know that we can count on
Mr. President, thank you first for the work accomplished and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the health check of the CAP, the report by Mr. Cabulos Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, as is too often seen, on territories and employment.
The elimination of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.

Decoupling, for example, poses a genuine difficulty for certain livestock territories, particularly those focused on beef cattle and sheep farming, and I was pleased to have heard Mrs. Fischer Boel address this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that the strict adherence to historical references would severely hinder any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the question of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one, because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in rural communities.
Therefore, one must reflect on this second-tier issue without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Mr. Minister Jouillet is leaving us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have known.
I wish him good luck.

Madam President, I voted for the Perisch report concerning the integration of Océane 20 into the Single Ocean, and I must say with a heavy heart, because I believe that this Single Ocean is not a simplification and does not increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for winegrowers and the entire wine sector.
Last night, the commissioner attempted to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first WTO.
He is a true gentleman.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act presented to us by the Commission last June.

Indeed, as early as the 2000s, initiatives were undertaken targeting SMEs, and I am particularly thinking of our colleague Dominique Vlastoo’s excellent work on the SME charter, initiatives that were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they too often remained as mere aspirations.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are experiencing and whose consequences are particularly concerning for SMEs invite us to this, if need be.
In this regard, the Small Business Act is part of a new, decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Ms. Herzog’s report on Commission communication, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we wished to question the Council.

Dear Minister,

We have read with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know whether the European Council of 11 and 12 December next

will clearly outline its conclusions and provide a strong impetus to ensure that the overarching guiding principle of “think small first” is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We wish the Council to commit to the principle of the action plan annexed hereto, along with concrete measures.
In this regard, and within the limited time available to me, I will emphasize three areas where we require binding impetus.
Impact studies, which should be systematic and regularly monitored, with oversight from the European Parliament regarding the implementation of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
access to public procurement
The code of good conduct has no binding force. We must, collectively, be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more indispensable than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are sound, Minister, they must also incorporate support for supply.
There is an urgent need.
Please confirm the Council's willingness.

Mr. President, Minister, and Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ over 70% of the European Union’s workforce and account for 99% of European businesses.

But, as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now concerned and threatened by the financial crisis, because it diminishes household purchasing power and confidence, and impacts order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is consequently necessary to ensure their activities are supported by guaranteeing that banks provide effective access to the financing required for the continuation of their operations.
This is the crux of the conclusions from the Competitiveness Council of December 1st, which Mr. the Minister spoke about, and of the recovery plan approved by the European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I wanted to acknowledge the action plan for the Small Business Act for Europe.
It effectively translates the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle of prioritizing SMEs first, that is, European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner has said and as we all say, the Council must genuinely engage with the other institutions.
European Union, for this principle to be rendered effective now, it is necessary to move beyond declaration; it is necessary to transition to implementation across all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan represents a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wished, Minister, to commend the proactive approach of the French Presidency of the Union, which enabled the rapid translation of intentions into action.

Mr. President, Madam President-in-office, Commissioner, I offer my full support to the rapporteur, who defends the position that was ours in first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
Mr. President, it was urgent to align our legislation on custody time with the Court of Justice’s case law, and that has now been accomplished.
The CERCAS report provides balanced and protective answers for employees.
All on-call time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest follows immediately after the period of service.
It is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, particularly for medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing the individual opt-out.
The CERCAS report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogation from the legal maximum working time.
We must face reality.
It is a jest to say that an employee finds themselves in a position of equality with their employer and can refuse what is proposed to them.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly demonstrate to the governments of the Member States that the text they wish to impose on us is unacceptable.

Amidst the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly fill the ears of the French government starting tomorrow, it seems to me necessary to focus above all on the employees who will be called upon to work ever more without truly having a choice, just as all those who will be asked to work on Sundays in France.
It is, moreover, evidently to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its position on individual opt-outs within the Council.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call, so that the negative votes in the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums are not followed by many others, questioning a European Union that would leave them with the feeling of not addressing their everyday concerns.
Mr. President, this was a very fine French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices, to say the least.
The twenty-seven set aside their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this, that first step is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without, however, sacrificing its economy.
She can, from now on, take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Furthermore, Ireland offers a scenario for escaping its isolation.
Our Irish friends will pronounce themselves once again on the Treaty of Lisbon with all the cards in hand, since practically all other members will have definitively declared their position.
Current crises demonstrate that the Union needs, more than ever, the best institutional tools to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors most severely affected.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his perspective.
We hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, an agreement that appeared impossible to heads of state and government last weekend.
The trials faced by Europeans offer the Union an opportunity to demonstrate itself as more united, more responsive, and more committed to protecting them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having instilled this new dynamic.
We wish, like Nicolas Sarkozy, not to see again so soon the councils of yesterday which ended at four in the morning to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the past six months, Europe has indeed changed its mindset, its scope, its credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this; we are well aware that it is not entirely unrelated.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.
But we demand that the Security Council take a stance, that the relevant bodies take a stance, that the European Union take a stance, and we, in Parliament, discuss and do not want to take a stance.

I believe that, even so, in the face of the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of extreme importance that this Parliament takes a position and clearly states what it wants to do to stop the massacres currently occurring in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament has not demonstrated the courage and clarity of mind to pass a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group requests a revision of the Conference of Presidents’ decision and the completion of the debate that we have, that we must.
We must consider the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament’s clear and firm position – a majority position – to ensure an end to the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution; we must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion, it must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we denounce.
Mr. President, Commissioner, more than ever, the draft directive that Parliament is preparing to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr. Klinz, has for years carried out sustained work and that he has negotiated with talent, notably during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has seen a number of significant advancements, moving towards better functioning of the internal market, collective management of financial assets, and welcomed as such by the European investment funds industry.

It remains the case that debates and discussions at the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For certain actors, it was imperative, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to fault; the passport holds up perfectly well. However, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of a passport for management companies…
It comes with necessary guarantees, particularly regarding fund supervision, as it leads to a dissociation of functions beyond borders.
Alternatively, I observe with regret that the system in place is not only complex, but also subject to divergent interpretations.
It risks very soon encountering practical difficulties that will harm the European export fund industry, particularly regarding exports to third countries.
I have duly noted that my position is in the minority; nevertheless, I do not feel uncomfortable.
Under normal circumstances, I would have been inclined to say that only practice will allow for definitive conclusions to be drawn in the matter and thus to determine
Who is correct, those who trust in the adaptive capacities of market actors and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
It is not out of the question that success lies ahead, but, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
Alternatively, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial collective asset management industry, do not reassure us.
Skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we are witnessing this already.
It may be that fundamental re-evaluations are necessary in this context of crisis.

That, within this context of profound crisis, we make choices that dilute the responsibilities of actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities can truly be seen as an incongruity.
I tell you, as I think, this directive is also that of a bygone era, prior to the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is set to experience a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence, and entire sections of its architecture must be reconsidered.

Let us not forget that the primary function of OCPs is to protect the investor through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting this text as it stands, without truly knowing where we are going, we are acting as if nothing had happened.
This autism bodes nothing good, which is why I will abstain, even though I signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances and the improvements made, it seems to me that insufficient weight has been given to the principles I have just outlined.

Mr. President, although the regulations concerning the reporting of animals have been in effect since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not consistently complying by providing, as required, annual reports.
Therefore, a global analysis remains probabilistic, as numerous elements are lacking regarding the means implemented to conduct inspections.
Mr. President, member of animal protection associations and member of the animal rights intergroup, this matter concerns me particularly.
Associations have desperately fought for decades, only to see guidelines established in this area in 2007, revealing a certain leniency on the part of Member States.
I would even go so far as to say a certain reluctance, for, ultimately, we know that implementing controls and inspections is not insurmountable.
We know the slaughter locations, we know the rearing locations, we know the transit routes of livestock, so where is the problem?

I believe that in our era, where public opinion is increasingly, and rightly, sensitized by the welfare of animals—whether concerning farming conditions, slaughtering practices, or transportation—it is important that states respect these sentiments.

Since I have been given the floor, I would like to add, with regard to transportation, that it would be essential to examine and take into account, irrespective of transportation durations, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour transport conducted in the Netherlands in springtime is not comparable to the same transport time in full summer in a country such as Greece.
Should night transport services not be mandated in these latter cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Madam President, I am pleased that it is a Briton, our colleague Parrish, who has submitted this text, as it underscores how the Romanian soldiers, two years ago, did well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then, two consequences must be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable symbolically to place the Food Agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not reconsider the following points: first, reinstate subsidies for almond growers; second, cease

The attacks against olive trees, particularly in Andalusia and throughout Europe, must cease. Stop the attacks against red tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean and the attacks against the European vineyard through buyouts.
I suggest to our Commissioner, our President, Mr. Barroso, that he organize a grand banquet in Portugal with sheep’s cheeses and wine.
Mr. President, we have indeed all campaigned for the closure of Guantanamo and we have all welcomed President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not arise for us.
As Europeans faithful to our values of defending human rights, we must take our responsibilities, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
We have been able to read, and here I address the Council, that some Member States were not particularly keen on this reception.
There, I would genuinely like to issue a call to the Council and, in particular, to the hesitant Member States, urging them to accept these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be for the welcome momentum generated by the closure of Guantánamo to become bogged down because we failed to answer the call when Europe needed us.

It is important, as the European animal feed sector constitutes one of the most significant sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production—representing half of the European Union’s agricultural output (120 million tonnes)—and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union, in fact, counts five million livestock farmers and sixty million households owning companion animals.

In the past, the European Union has had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant regarding transparency to meet the expectations of both farmers and consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of representing a minimal cost for industries and a significant benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.

The adoption of this report will help to limit risks by ensuring better product quality, improved control, enhanced traceability, and comprehensive information for the breeder and, ultimately, the consumer.

Today, with the increase in international exchanges, it is more than imperative to strengthen any preventative measures to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past are not repeated.

Mr. President, this report successfully balances the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must be mandatory on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so vital for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

Mr. President, I believe that, indeed, manufacturers should have the obligation to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering into the composition of animal feed, in order to guarantee transparency and facilitate the control performed by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the introduction of a new hazardous substance into the list of prohibited materials seems absolutely essential to me.

Similarly, affording the breeder the opportunity to query the competent national authority or the European Commission in cases of doubt regarding a misleading claim allows for greater diversification of systems, protects the consumer while preserving the integrity of commercial transactions.

I would therefore like to offer my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation of pet food labelling – I conclude, Mr. President – prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control, is the best guarantee of preventing future health crises in Europe.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Affairs Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they do today for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan.
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans finance reconstruction.
This is how tasks are divided among allies.
Alternatively, it would be necessary for the vandals to pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks concerning an extended ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable, as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of a far-right faction democratically accepted there, risks seeing its task significantly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.

Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become in the West Bank a sort of international protectorate, the legitimacy of which has significantly diminished among the population.
The final element to consider is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never ceased since 1967, rendering the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks on both sides accept this truce of God that both parties demand without providing the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a thought regarding France’s reintegration into NATO’s integrated military structure, which will be debated in light of the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will entail severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO while the Cold War has been over for 90 years.
Sarkozy appears to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should we reinforce the logic of blocs at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including on the military level, are occurring?
Furthermore, France’s accession to the integrated structure will oblige it to reinforce its contingent in Afghanistan, while it already has 3 personnel deployed there.
With what budget will she finance it, when her defense budget is going to fall below 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments are to be disbanded?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budgetary contribution to join NATO and, at the same time, reduce our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
It merely required reading the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, relying in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this quite remarkable synthesis they have produced of the current state of our foreign policy and common security policy.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place rightfully assigned to it by its economic and demographic strength and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

Forced to acknowledge that, despite the consistent will expressed by more than two-thirds of our European citizens—as you yourself stated—certain progress has indeed been made over the past ten years, I concede that much, but forced to acknowledge that this Europe still does not exist.
If an illustration were needed, his erasure from the solution to the new drama in the Middle East would serve to demonstrate it.
There has been, and continues to be, a need for European presence in Gaza to play an active role, both in assisting the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the
within the country and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had enabled this territory to be transformed into a launch base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the kind words lavished on Charmélcher and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

Mr. President, I reiterate here a question already raised during the Lebanese crisis: when, Mr. High Representative, can we hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we did in response to piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Gentlemen the Commissioner, the President, dear colleagues, the Parliament’s decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council regarding the settlement of the matter was not taken.
The handling of this file has been unanimous, both at the fisheries commission last week and this morning, here in plenary session.
We are indeed all aware of the need for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the relevant international commission, the CICTA.
This concerns specifically implementing the recommendations adopted by this organization to address the persistent overfishing of Atlantic bluefin tuna.
in the East Atlantic and in the Mediterranean and to confront the serious danger that stems from it for the future of the species and therefore that of fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Fisheries Commission, Ms. Fraga and Mr. Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak on the matter within the scope of this debate.
For my part, I would like to recall the importance our committee attaches to this file, which involves the principal dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely management
regarding resource management, fleet management, compliance with international, regional, and bilateral agreements, technical measures, and above all, control—I will return to that shortly.
This dossier, therefore, constitutes in our view a test of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question that the implementation of the new recovery plan would proceed without consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only path legally and politically acceptable for the implementation of the agreement.
recommendations of the CETA, namely the proposal for a properly enacted regulation based on Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments undertaken by the Commission on behalf of the European Union within regional fisheries management organisations is, indeed, not a trivial operation, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
At bottom, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although restrictive for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges, and I emphasize that the most significant are as follows.
The most important measures are certainly those that will concern control, for it is true that, without control, no restoration plan can demonstrate effectiveness.
I therefore thank you, Commissioner, for this proposal, and I invite you to demonstrate the same circumspection.
determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, as you demonstrated in reaching an agreement satisfactory at the CICTA level.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have yet to undertake a concrete definition of territorial cohesion.
The French presidency is being tested there, and I wish to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be specified as soon as possible.

I wish, following the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooij, that territorial cohesion should become the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all regions of the Union and enabling the fullest possible exploitation of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target exclusively regions suffering from permanent handicaps.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept appears to me to be relevant for taking into account the outermost regions, in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for having incorporated in his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, essential components of territorial cohesion.
Upon reading the Commission’s recent communication, entitled RUPs: An Asset for Europe, it appears to me that it intends to apply the entirety
recommendations concerning the improvement of governance in cohesion matters, thereby constituting the first, somewhat premature, illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I wish that the Estates General of Overseas France, which will soon begin in France, will proceed in the same manner and broadly integrate the major territorial impact of European policies supporting REA, whose added value is undeniable.
irreversible and undisputed.
One enjoys reading the conclusions of the presidency of the latest Council.
It resembles the victory communiqué of all defeated armies.
They mock it, up to the reiterated assertion that, the crisis ending, the Union will build a stronger economy for the future or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in complete disarray.
Thus, as they enclose themselves within their glass tower, Eurocrats, Europhiles, and Europians of every stripe ultimately lose sight of the bigger picture.
Everyone knows that the Eurozone was the first to enter a recession, having experienced the lowest growth rate globally for eight years.
But it is also the one that faces the greatest difficulties regarding its industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, through the general disarmament of natural defenses stripped from nations, is the least equipped to react.
In reality, the sole merit of this crisis will be to awaken peoples lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by nationalistic propaganda.
Only states will possess the legitimate instruments necessary for any significant action, and they will need, for this, to challenge the constraints of the Union and the euro.
For the French, at any rate, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that, indeed, the question of the distribution of food supplies to benefit the most vulnerable is entirely opportune, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission's proposal does not address the issue.
The issue of co-financing raises questions for me, and I believe it is rather the question of liberalism that has guided the evaluations of the CAP in recent years and which must be challenged.
Riots against hunger, the abrupt fluctuations in food prices, are persistent indicators of the limits of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore advocate for policy to reclaim its authority, to take control, both at the European and global levels, and for the strategic domain of agriculture and human food supply, both quantitatively and qualitatively, not to be subjected to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is a sense of urgency, and the Zykerski report responds to this urgency, which I welcome, but I wish that, in the case of the reflection that is opening up on
Regarding the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the primary objective remains to structurally combat hunger and poverty as we know them in all Member States and throughout the world.
Rural territories are available to meet food needs with sufficient and quality production; however, will they be given the financial and human resources to ensure this heavy responsibility?
Mr. President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and its Member States together contributed 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world's leading donor.
European development funds enable the fight against poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that, for ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for the period 2008 under the tenth European Development Fund, representing practically double the amount foreseen for the ninth EDF.
The French Court of Accounts, in its report, concludes that the accounts of the seventh, eighth, and ninth FEDs are, in general, faithful, legal, and regular.
One can only welcome the record levels of contract implementation and disbursement of European Funds.
However, I also note that progress must be pursued to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as a significant level of errors continues to affect certain transactions.
Similarly, there is a risk that is too often overestimated regarding budgetary support, and it is, in my opinion, necessary to better assess these risks.
On this subject, I share the view that budgetary support should be granted only if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage funds transparently, responsibly, and effectively.

Mr. President, among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FEP into the general budget, I will conclude regarding the Community’s, as this would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

To conclude, Mr. President, I also wished to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the Commission staff who did an excellent job on the ground, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, the Parliament and its rapporteur were compelled to reject a flawed compromise; they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted overwhelmingly at the plenary session, which called for the eventual elimination of all exemptions from the legal working week.
But the truth is that the Parliament was alone in wanting to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided far beyond partisan divisions to end this archaism known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers superbly ignored, as did the Commission.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any advancement of workers’ rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your objectives.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all custody time as working time; therefore, you have lost nothing in that regard.
The opt-out you desire still exists in practice; real estate has therefore prevailed.
More than ever, the deputies elected next June will have to strive for a top-down harmonization of social standards.
Ah! But that's right!

Mr. President, this is certainly not on behalf of the LIBE Committee, but most likely on behalf of my group. I would like to use this brief minute to express my extraordinarily positive assessment of Ms. Paganov’s report.
I congratulate you, Madam, on your report.

I believe that in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise specification of elements that should feature prominently, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, of which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to everything that has been said, regarding the importance of judicial training and evaluation, to emphasize two fundamental elements in terms of mutual trust that underpin what could be, tomorrow, mutual recognition.
One, the independence of the judiciary.
Currently, within the Union, there are a number of countries in which the judiciary's independence from political power or other powers has not been established.
It is a scandal, and this scandal must cease.
Secondly, procedural safeguards.

As long as we are not certain that, in a number of countries, individuals suspected or accused of committing certain types of offenses benefit from procedural safeguards analogous to those that exist elsewhere, it is difficult to secure widespread acceptance of the principle of mutual recognition.
It is a fundamental element, and I wanted to introduce it into this discussion.
Congratulations to Madame Pagat.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be the only ones to condemn it.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of la Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union as represented by the Commission,

In the United States, a significant number of countries, including my own and Norway, to speak of countries in the European continent, have condemned the coup d'état, because we must call a spade a spade, which occurred in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we demand a return to constitutional legality.
We never demand a recall of shares, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or a referendum.
It falls to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
Therefore, what we are requesting with this resolution, is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signify to those who have seized power in a wholly

in a democratic manner and in the guise of a coup d'état, however well disguised, to return to Madagascar’s constitutional legality, which is one of the guarantees of its future development, this great island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, naturally I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, for the continued attention he gives to all these disasters.
We worked together extensively when President Barroso had asked me to prepare a report, which he subsequently cited, on the creation of a European Civil Protection Force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I find myself thinking that it remains remarkably relevant.
Madame Zavala, of course, there is more to it than just Greece.
All countries are affected, and I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and how many others, of industrial accidents of the type of Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters besides wildfires.
I am thinking about the tsunami.
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we deploy are not up to the scale of these disasters that are going to multiply under the combined effect of global warming and transportation.
That is why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all of his teams, and the Directorate-General that operates the civil protection mechanism.
I believe we must go further.
With those member states that desire it, enhanced cooperation may be envisioned.
If we are not twenty-seven to form this civil defense force, let us begin with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I make a list of disasters, I can say that everyone is affected—the floods that struck Germany in 2002, and even major pandemics, as well as terrorism.
There, Monsieur le Commissaire, why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
Our Parliament, the Environment Committee, and the Defence and Security Committee will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen Deputies, this summer again, the Mediterranean forest has been ravaged by flames in Marseille, in Southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and, on a larger scale, in Greece.
More than 400 hectares of forests and fields have been reduced to ashes, triggering substantial material debates, irreversible damage to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human life.
Deeply concerned by this recurring annual record and aware of the multiplier effect of climate change on fires,
I call for a European awareness-raising effort to improve coordination and pool resources for firefighting.
I wish to see the realization of a large-scale Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat wildfires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I commend the existing initiatives, and in particular the European forest fire information system, pilot project.
Nevertheless, I advocate for a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a high-performing tool for responding to crises and a reinforcement of European strength.
and of the Euro Aid mechanism conceived by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene within the territory of the twenty-seven member countries as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of wildfires lies in the exchange of knowledge and best practices in prevention, and I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by forest firefighters in my own department.
I can readily place this example, which may be useful, at Europe's disposal.
Mr. President, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I will be brief.
I believe there are two elements in this debate.
The conjuncture question: how to exit this crisis?
All measures that both assist farmers and constitute interventions are necessary and absolutely essential.
They must be supported, and even considered to be more important.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a question posed in a structural manner concerning the management of the milk market, and it is there that there is a divergence with you, Madam Commissioner.
You propose moving in the direction of contractualization.
I am telling you this in advance: contractualizing between industrialists and farmers, in the long run, with industries competing with one another, will lead to competition on a European scale.
We require, in order to regulate a market, public regulation.
There is no other alternative.
That is where the debate will need to begin following this crisis.
I believe that, on this debate, all opinions and all options must be respected, and I fear we moved too quickly during the health assessment to resolve a matter like quotas.

To date, I say this to all those who have intervened, we have enabled both the maintenance of dairy production in Europe, the assurance of a highly developed dairy industry, and, simultaneously, the assurance of a price for consumers that has been, until now, entirely bearable.
Mr. President, just a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I genuinely feel that we can say that we are today more European than before.
I truly rejoiced, fully, serenely.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we remain essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech president.
A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold in their hands the future of this treaty, crucial for the Union, for our institutions, and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few whose sole aim is to undermine the broader European interest.
It is legitimate for some to wish not to go further in European integration, it is legitimate to express these reservations, but it is also legitimate to allow those who wish to do so to progress.
Generally, the processes of ratification of European treaties too often take the form of a saga or a victory achieved through a sudden turn.
We are condemned to constantly having to push for the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms.
We must draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this commitment to negotiation concerning the organization of a second
I would like a referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to re-vote a people who have expressed themselves sovereignly and as if it were normal that assent to a treaty could be a bargaining chip.
It concerns the consistency and institutional balance of the European endeavor.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses that one’s country adheres to the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June 2009.
What do you believe the citizen thinks today of the Treaty of Lisbon and, beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Mr. President, my intervention concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world’s workers earn less than two dollars per day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery, and over 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization counts 160 deaths annually related to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those deprived of employment and social rights, who work in conditions unworthy of human dignity.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancers or chronic illnesses due to their working conditions.
It is time to move beyond the religion of working more, the pursuit of profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union’s priorities over the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To rise to the challenge, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our committee chair for the environment, Joleen Anoui, specified earlier. An alliance of all—industrialized nations, emerging economies—is necessary.

Today, with our debate and also the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we once again call on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is fitting that we speak with a single voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must, in Copenhagen, sign an agreement to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1990 levels.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to substantially reduce their emissions, but also that developing countries contribute to achieving the goals.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must therefore allow developing countries to transition towards low-carbon models.
Allow me, as well, to address two avenues that seem necessary for our future.
First, the global implementation of climate change mitigation funding based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Subsequently, it appears necessary to implement a fiscal adjustment at the borders of Europe that would target imports of products manufactured without any regard for environmental protection.

This involves a contractual arrangement and a transfer to Southern countries of the carbon tax collected at the borders of Europe, which would serve to finance investments in the equipment necessary for combating global warming.

Mr. President, I would like to speak along the same lines as my remarks yesterday concerning the preparation for the Copenhagen summit, and following, moreover, yesterday’s ECOFIN meeting, which was not a success.
I raised the issue with you regarding the responsibility we, as industrialized nations, have to ensure that developing countries can keep pace with our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities, otherwise that would mean we are all starting from the same point to ultimately achieve nothing.

Therefore, to convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously need to address the issue of the assistance that should be provided to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the twenty-seven must absolutely agree on how the European Union envisions aid to developing countries within the significant context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I was saying, the Council and the Financial Council failed to reach a common position on this issue.
However, we know that this question is absolutely central.

The European Commission had already made proposals, and I absolutely wish that we take the initiative to guide our partners towards a global solidarity necessary to overcome this problem of climate change.
Mr. President, I commend the efforts of the Swedish Presidency to achieve an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe that admitting at this stage that the Copenhagen summit was stillborn or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement ratified by all parties does not demonstrate realism.
Let us not succumb too readily to pessimism.
I advocate that, at this stage, we do not scale back our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and legally binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legally sound treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline for the COP 16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
We must clarify our commitment in terms of financial resources and assistance to developing countries, particularly regarding technology transfer.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary impetus given, or to speak of it, by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, and Norway, among others, who have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While understanding the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate question, we must nonetheless achieve quantified, binding, and ambitious commitments in the short, medium, and long term from other major polluters, such as the United States and China.
Lacking alternatives, we head toward climatic, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and we have all said the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I wish to state very clearly that the European Union must be capable of saying no and refusing to sign a watered-down agreement.
The European populations we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that will allow us to effectively combat all the climate disruptions we observe daily around us.
They will not settle for mere publicity stunts, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives upon which one can simply walk away once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, the States must commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to foresee concrete, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot shoulder the burden of this effort alone.

That is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to assume their share of the burden, we must draw all the consequences from this by establishing at our borders a tax protecting our industry from the competition of those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We, Europeans, demand a little more each day from our industrialists.
I would like the climate package, signed under the French presidency, as evidence.

I would like to cite as evidence the national initiatives that, like the carbon tax praised earlier by Mr. Pargno—a development I applaud—are promoting the establishment of an ecological taxation system.

A sector such as transportation, which ranks among the largest emitters of CO2—even though certain modes of transport, like aviation, emit fewer greenhouse gases—is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
Alternatively, this is a sector that has been severely affected by the fallout from the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are integrated into the Copenhagen negotiations, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries is also asked of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, global public opinion will have its eyes fixed on its ruling class. Please finish, if you please. Do not disappoint us, thank you.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen Summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We too must call on our leaders to create an international organization, such as the WTO, tasked with regulating climate change and environmental issues, and to establish a fund
in addition, of course, to public development aid, to create a maritime and aviation carbon tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We readily recognize the pressing need for global environmental regulation, as well as that of financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this journey through history by means of the environment.
Let us proceed in accordance with our loftiest human aspirations, otherwise we shall appear as actors without any grasp of reality.

Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, less than two weeks before the Copenhagen conference, concerns are mounting regarding the success of climate change negotiations.
Some are already saying that it will be a failure.
Major global powers are still reluctant to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of them.

By adopting the resolution tomorrow on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen conference, we, Members of the European Parliament, must demonstrate that our determination is first and foremost absolute, and that the conference must result in an agreement that is certainly precise but, above all, binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once found, must not be open to challenge or doubt.

We cannot indefinitely postpone the decision until tomorrow, or it will be too late. Hence, the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be brought under the auspices of the UN to oversee the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must, from Copenhagen onwards, be able to expect greater lucidity and responsibility from the world’s major religious denominations.

Mr. President, I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British socialist government and the French government, aimed at returning Afghans in an irregular situation to their territories.
Indeed, contrary to what some have claimed, these individuals had their request for political asylum rejected, and this bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.

The migratory pressure is a challenge that we must collectively address, and this is the purpose of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, voted for several months ago, adopted several months ago under the French presidency.
Now, it is necessary to move forward by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven to request that the Commission conduct a study on this subject is a first step, and, Commissioner, I wish the Commission to support this proposal, as the fight against illegal immigration is an expectation of public opinion and, particularly, of immigrant populations in regular status.
Mr. President, I would like to revisit a recent event: the Swiss vote on minarets.
Indeed, this vote took place in a state that is not a member of the European Union, but it is evident that it concerns a matter not unfamiliar to us.
I would like to revisit this event because I also see it as an opportunity to discuss secularism, and we never speak enough about secularism in this forum.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism governs the organization of our society, and I would like to state here some simple things.
First, let it be understood that the contrary principle of secularism is not religious belief, nor still less spirituality.

The principle contrary to secularism is religious communautarism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil law, the communautarism that confines individuals within groups subservient to society.
Our Union, through its history, is multicultural and multiethnic.
She is and she will be even more so, and only secularism can allow individuals
Mr. President, the CESAR program, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of redeployment of these arts, and in particular, the funding of this essential program for the environment, as well as for our scientific and technical influence?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, which stipulates that a suitably qualified high-level figure should ensure the political oversight of this programme?

Indeed, it will require overcoming numerous legal, psychological, and technical obstacles in unifying national airspaces and ensuring that air traffic controllers from different countries work together.
If Europe is unable to unify its airspace, how will it be capable of constructing a strong political entity?
Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in question.

These impacts, in the short, medium, or long term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESE in a certain national newspaper are making headlines and certainly reinforcing the positions of skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to acknowledge, act, and rectify the effects of climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this forum, not only due to the bold legislation that is ours regarding the limitation of the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a sense of disappointment, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting temperature increases to two degrees, and this even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated considerable ambition regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
So I think of Japan and Norway.
Furthermore, it is also important to emphasize the highly positive aspect of the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions resulting from deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained regarding the implementation of the IRED Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO2 storage.
Far from a binding agreement but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen conference, as did many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to witness a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe.
My disappointment was considerable, as Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, and particularly when it came to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on the matter.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not yield results, and our representatives were uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Heidegger, drawing on her proposals and commitments made before the environment committee, will be able to raise the ambitions of the European Union.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, in order to avoid the caricatures—we have heard a few this morning—I would like to recall some objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average per capita income and, now, the vast majority of Tunisians fall within the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

Over 90% of Tunisians benefit from social security, and more than a quarter of Tunisia’s budget is allocated to education, meaning that the country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals regarding primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel recalled earlier, the rights of women are recognized and guaranteed.
At the university, female students outnumber male students; 40% of the professors are women, as are a quarter of the members of parliament, local elected officials, or journalists.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr. President, the acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unfair to hold Egypt and Egyptians accountable for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be prosecuted.
Let us not conflate the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country, nor make a false equivalence between fanatics and an entire population. Finally, in pretending to interpose
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we provide arguments to extremists who seek to portray Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
Please excuse me, Madame la Présidente, Madame la Présidente, Ladies and Gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, in Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or in Ireland is scandalous.

These very Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently noted the swindlers emitting and trading toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now of the utmost severity toward the states that rushed to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis triggered by the irresponsibility of markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of deficits and public debt that these very markets now claim to sanction.
That concludes the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union, and the G20.

All that bankers have taken away from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of profit and insurance resources, as the word is out that the scale of this panic stems from a large American bank that benefited from government assistance.

of the American state and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to profit both from the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and from the CDS market, these insurance policies on state loans which themselves are the subject of independent speculation.
It will not suffice to regulate hedge funds, which you fear doing, or the markets for derivative instruments, as Mr. Barnier proposes.
It is pointless to create a European economic government.
The twenty-seven are, in any case, in the same boat, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free global circulation of capital that must be questioned, otherwise there will be
Mr. President, less than 15% of the original stock of that red wine remains today.
Faced with such figures, the solution appears obvious.
Nevertheless, we must not overlook the positions affected by the decision that concerns us today.
It must be recalled that CITES is not intended to prohibit fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80% of which is exported to Japan.

By conserving tuna, we are certainly protecting a species dangerously sought after, but we are also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced and sustainable fishing activity—fishing intended for our domestic market and a source of employment.

Mr. President, I am in favor of listing the red tuna in Annex 1 of CITES, and while I believe this decision will be positive, I would appreciate the Commission's assistance in enabling a profound restructuring of the fishing sector.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is requesting a suspension of eighteen months, along with financial measures for the sailors and shipowners affected by a trade ban.
What is the Commission’s view on the matter?
Furthermore, like many of my colleagues, my concern centers on equity.
How can we ensure that vessels flagged in countries such as Tunisia, Libya, or others will apply the ban on international trade with a level of rigor comparable to our own?
What will the new control and sanction measures be?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary for the implementation of these measures.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this directive proposal indeed follows a vote in Parliament, and you have also recalled this, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we seek to support.
In seeking to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust essential to their management and the dynamism of their operations.
First, I believe it is important to be clear about thresholds and what are known as microentities.
These are SMEs with more than ten employees and a turnover exceeding one million euros.
Whatever the member states, they represent a very large majority of businesses.
