Certainly, they may be local and have a limited presence on the community market, but that does not negate the need for them to present accounting rules, and that
Accounting rules will have to be confronted each time they wish to deal with a banking institution, with partners, or sometimes negotiate with fiscal, economic, and social institutions.

At that point, accounting regulations will be imposed upon them, and they may have to pay more than they would for standard accounting in order to satisfy criteria that they may not necessarily understand.
I do not see any advantage in imposing accounting obligations outside of a common framework within the European Union.
It is not simply a matter of competition; it is fundamentally a question of economic integration, of Community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
That being said, it is obviously a necessity to simplify accounting obligations for SMEs.
Three initiatives, moreover, are moving in that direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today, or the IF international framework.
I would prefer that it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should shortly be making proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010; it appears they are being extended, but I do not believe this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half-hearted job, because these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same articulation, and it seems to me, Mr. Commissioner,

It is clearer for businesses to provide them with a single, comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying obligations desired by all with the practical realities of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of this directive, and this is detrimental to our deliberations.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of exemptions, which currently divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact study.

Mr. President, Commissioner, and dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and other colleagues have indicated, the violent storm Xintia struck several French regions on February 27 and 28, resulting in 53 fatalities and considerable property damage.
The storm was of exceptional intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coastline.
Following Madeira, Europe is concerned once again.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared natural disaster areas: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and the Loire Valley.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial assistance that we will be able to support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Bécuy joins me in this endeavor, the European Commission to promptly release the Union Solidarity Fund to assist affected regions in coping with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier’s proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands of the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jürg Leichtfried, on his report and his spirit of cooperation on this matter, and I particularly support his proposals on the funding of air safety, since we are talking about air safety here, and not air security.

It has been many years that our Commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that the strictest security measures must be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not concern only travelers, but concerns all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on aircraft.
And this is all the more so because, in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, States finance, depending on the case, partially or fully the safety measures.
I therefore believe that we must remain steadfast in our stance towards the Council and defend amendment 32 of the report adopted by our transport committee to the very end.
I had another point to address briefly.

While I support the progress in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of security levies.
While obliging adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system for collecting fees.

Thus, in countries such as Spain, Italy, or France, levies are voted on by Parliament and, in such cases, it must be the authority for recourse against laws that serves as an independent supervisory body.
And that is the object of amendment 40, which I hope you will support in large numbers when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature this week reminds us that volcanoes, in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
This still requires, however, that men and Europe in particular take responsibility for combating what is known as global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil fuels, and, above all, on the other hand,
Moncotte has participated very actively in carbon sequestration to globally reduce carbon emissions and increase carbon fixation and storage.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, a shift is needed from an approach, how shall I put it, compartmentalized, which consists of, each time a problem arises, opening a directive.
On the soils, on the water, on pesticides, what else do I know, and to try to approach the agricultural question with the ambition of addressing it globally, systematically.
In this approach, we must be able to find avenues to ensure that agriculture, as I was saying earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively participates in carbon sequestration.
It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is dear to me, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this avenue, which I am opening in this report and which I hope will be followed during the vote to be held in plenary session in Brussels, should enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

a transition to ecological agriculture, which would place it ahead of a number of other continents or agricultural systems, ensuring its capacity for economic, ecological, and, I believe, social performance from that point forward.

This report addresses a specific issue—the fight against global warming and agriculture—but it aspires, I hope, to open up other perspectives for informing, in particular, the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I address the Commission, I will address, and I have often addressed, the agricultural committees; I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I believe we need to take a turn.
This CAP of 2013 must be ambitious.
She must rely on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy, because Europe's agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
That is, in any case, what I propose in this report, and that is what I hope the Parliament, in a large majority, will follow.

Mr. President, I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our citizens must take precedence over all other considerations, and under these conditions, the attitude of certain airlines who are requesting the total and immediate reopening of airspace on the basis of one or two test flights appears, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Henain earlier who spoke of the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train, and I will seize the opportunity to say how much I regret that the air traffic paralysis
has been accentuated in certain countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I wish to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
And it is a common-sense decision in a context already marked by crisis, but these measures must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I wish that among the criteria retained for their awarding, the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation allocated to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations be included.
Indeed, it is unacceptable that certain airlines abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers as mandated by Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, furthermore, bear the financial cost.
Furthermore, travel agencies are relieved of the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And that, either, is not normal.

Companies, such as travel agencies, have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, such as the situation we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for cancelled flights.
Mr. President, turmoil, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster – words are not lacking in the press to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly when lamenting the colossal, abyssal—one might be tempted to say—financial impact of this crisis, in direct or indirect terms.

While I welcome the prospect of considering the allocation of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, already substantially approved since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed by the European management of events.

Knowing that 750 European passengers were injured, a significant portion of whom remain stranded across the globe. Knowing that the economic losses are exponential with the passage of time, how can one explain that it took

It does not take one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one contests the necessity of applying the precautionary principle with absolute priority, but today, as traffic is progressively reauthorized in areas

secured, with unchanged weather conditions, and while the volcano remains active, one is justified in asking what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.

Thirdly, an evolving action model has been developed—evolution according to weather and volcanic activity can change hour by hour—which will continue to proceed with the updated assessment of corridor safety.
Should these test flights be conducted by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this situation persists, worsens, or recurs—which is likely—the management model in place will need to incorporate greater coordination among Member States and special operational procedures based on real data.

coordination of other modes of transport, in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into consideration the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who are also entitled to information and assistance.
Alternatively, until now, only isolated and national initiatives have been undertaken.
Madam President, I wanted, after other speakers, to express my thanks to our colleague Méndez de Vigo, who has accomplished remarkable work under sometimes heated and always engaging conditions.
The debates within the professional affairs committee were protracted, commensurate with the stakes and the intensity of the interest clearly demonstrated by the countries involved.
The European Parliament, whose primary concern, legitimately and above all else, relates to the composition of our assembly and the modalities for designating its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has managed to gather opinions and contributions that were sometimes divergent and, I would say, synthesize into an extremely balanced text the opinions and views.
I wanted to thank him for it.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports—both concerning the calling of the General Council and concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our assembly—are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
I believe that, broadly speaking, on other subjects as well, this is what citizens expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalli, Mr. Commissioner, with considerable force, this draft report, as just presented by Mr. Peterle, reiterates the Commission’s lines.
This is the communication directive of the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to endorse the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether concerning the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and, above all, the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and apprehensions expressed within the European Commission’s communication and the draft report.
I wish to acknowledge the work done by Mr. Peterle, rapporteur, in the drafting of this report and the compromise proposals put forward to address the various amendments.

As rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats group, I have wished, among other things, to emphasize the following points: first, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens at the workplace, but also the importance of improved access

information on medications for cancer patients, as well as the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern containing carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods

containing carcinogenic chemical substances and to strengthen the control of the presence of chemical substances within the European Union and, finally, to develop guidelines for a common definition of disability that may include individuals suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
Here are the questions we wished to pose while offering our support for this report project.
Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Bay of Mexico is a veritable ecological and economic catastrophe.
It appears that irregularities were observed in the granting of forest permits by the United States Department of the Interior.
This would be a most unforgivable carelessness, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.
When we know that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same laxity, it would pose serious problems for the entire world.
elected officials from European outermost regions and islands PTOMs, almost entirely islands, nearly 130
In total, spread across the three continents, I must express here my very great concern regarding our islands with respect to offshore petroleum exploitation projects.
This is precisely why it is imperative that the European Union, leading by example, rigorously reviews safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Furthermore, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily attributable to Europe, are estimated at tens of thousands of tonnes annually.

Wouldn't it be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms are now overseen by an undisputed international scientific authority, established in the form of an international body?
Following Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate genuine global governance for the research, protection, and exploitation of marine resources.

The continuity of the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean, represents an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
As the excellent report by Vincent Peillon points out, we cannot neglect either the potential of this region nor the perils it carries.
Yet, having the lucidity to recognize it since the bombardment of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is stalled.
We are not even certain that the summit planned for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn, in the coming hours or days, that it has been adjourned, suspended.
We must not, however, abandon hope, but the European Union must assume greater responsibility in seeking a political solution.
We cannot allow the United States to hold a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region underpin our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this concerns a matter of extreme importance regarding consumer protection.

A recent survey indicates that the situation regarding food security has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years, and one in three consumers remains wary of the quality of products.
Updating, simplifying, and clarifying the labeling of food products within the European Union is therefore an obligation for improved consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code provided that it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
Then, I oppose a mandatory nutrition declaration for wines and spirits.
We desire the development of regulations specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian vessels by Israeli commando units clearly calls for an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credence could we give a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters; it therefore concerns the international community, and is of particular interest to Europe bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe, which should make its voice heard more and become more deeply involved in seeking a political solution based on two states, each having Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but, unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary good will we demonstrate is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take steps to ensure our voice is heard.
The brutal killing of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army has provoked emotions and condemnations.
I wish to express my emotion regarding the nine victims of the civilian assault, a condemnation because this detention in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.
In doing so, the Israeli government penalizes its people because, ultimately, we see, with the strengthening of extremist factions, the ultimate goal of security in the region receding further.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must renounce the policy of force.
However, I wish to note that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I wish that the government of Israel would accept that this inquiry includes substantial international participation, so as to finally find its way back to justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, even if it served only that purpose, would at least have the merit of highlighting how essential Russia is as a geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks concerning cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
Some observations, however.

While the requirements of the Union are consistently emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner are systematically undervalued or dismissed, whether in the field of energy or in how it can analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness displayed by most Member States and by the Union in their discourse, the virulence of the condemnations and violations of human rights, appear reserved solely for Russia.

The statements are more akin to police work, the diplomacies more filtered, as if we were dealing with China, for example, and its systematic violations of the rule of law, not least concerning the Uyghurs in this global factory, in relation to minimal European social requirements, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to recall the adage of Adagusta, father of Augusta: toward the summits by narrow paths, for it is thus that I view the efforts of today’s Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, has bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has demonstrated the ability to raise the head of an entire nation, despite the significant difficulties and challenges that remain to be addressed.

So, a bit of modesty, gentlemen Europe experts, especially when the super European state itself fails to achieve any of its grand objectives despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive dominance of states in Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot also refrain from noting that this Assembly, in relation to the more communist, more indulgent Soviet Union, exhibited greater leniency than it did for Russia.

It is, moreover, often the same individuals who, yesterday, advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr. Gorbachev’s common house, who today experience the most virtuous indignations and the greatest reserve regarding the Union-Russia partnership.

On this subject, I must inform you, if you are not already, of new historical facts that will emerge from the progressive translation of Soviet secret archives procured by a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov, archives which have already yielded and will continue to yield abundantly.

It is an unpleasant surprise for the chief proponent of the single narrative regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was, truly, Mr. Gorbachev, and of the misdeed of today's European powers, who at the time eagerly sought to make certain Soviet projects feasible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, or common risks than are certain states that you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr. President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, an obviousness, let alone a necessity that has become unavoidable, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this capacity, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant leap toward genuine economic governance, for let us be clear, mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Could we have arrived at a genuine budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided upon it?
Let us return to the Council’s decisions that still please me.
Strengthening the preventative pillar of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no genuine fiscal discipline without sanctions for those who deviate from it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, regarding the decisions made, such as the celebrated competitiveness evaluation dashboard, because it is precisely about reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us again applaud the project of establishing a bank tax, the acceptance of a taxation of financial transactions, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, these decisions and orientations seemed, only a few months ago, or even a few weeks, unrealistic, illusory, or indeed genuinely hypothetical.
You are right; it's true, it's a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policymaking.
However, that being said, it is now absolutely necessary that in October, the states implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious wish, something we will all bitterly regret and, in particular, the majority, the citizens, will have to endure on a daily basis.

Mr. President, we have, in fact, already discussed this at the conference of presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and, evidently, Parliament, all groups still have a need to discuss because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we requested postponing the debate and vote on the Gallo report, that is to say, to September, September 2nd, when that will need to be addressed at the Conference of Presidents.
Therefore, it is a very straightforward matter.
Given that the fruit is not ripe, let us allow it the summer to ripen and discuss the matter in September.
Madam President, I confess I find it difficult to follow my colleagues who so enjoy showing off and claiming a monopoly on our legitimacy in relation to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often comical.
But when the members of this household, through diligent work and conviction, assert a reasoned position, when
We champion what appears to be a shared European interest against rigid states; the situation is changing drastically.
In this debate on European oversight, the Parliament played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur for my group, I have defended, as has the rapporteur, Ms. Goulard, an ambitious line.
I have advocated for mechanisms ensuring a certain efficiency and have emphasized the primacy of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution within this framework and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I feel compelled to withhold the names of all the institutions and all those prominent figures who vanished abruptly during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board during the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow the macroprudential oversight supported by a strong community institution, while microprudential oversight will necessarily remain fragmented.
Having been disconcerted, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start from a sound foundation, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the revision of the Industrial Emissions Directive is more than acceptable, and I commend the work of compromise that has been achieved.

This final package restates the key tax measures that I, along with several of my colleagues on the environment committee, advocated for, with the aim of making this legislation both ambitious and realistic.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and relevant authorities regarding the granting of exemptions.
Next, I wish to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, appears much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better coordination with the ETS Directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOx quotas.
Some caveats to bear in mind, however, and particularly those concerning land.
As the SOL directive remains pending, this significant issue will unfortunately be addressed only by Member States possessing their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogue negotiations.

A considerable amount of work has been undertaken on all sides to prevent the referral of this text to conciliation, a text which, I must reiterate, is of crucial importance both to industry and to European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings its share of information that reveals the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the offshore platform rupture.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind occur elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and has been happening for a long time, in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter regulations concerning platform management, not only European regulations but also international ones.
As for the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with measures to combat this disaster, and I believe it is evident.
I also believe that all of this argues, as Ms. Damanaki has said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
The European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur as the European Union prepares to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500 tonnes of beef.
A new market opening would occur to the detriment of livestock farmers in disadvantaged European regions, without a guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe purchases 38 million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunge.
Between 2001 and 2004, soybean cultivation destroyed over 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on regaining autonomy in plant-based proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally responsible agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be rendered null and void by this proposed bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and farmers to obtain random concessions for service companies.
These concessions will benefit no families of farmers in Mercosur, but the interests of agroindustrial groups.
To be convinced, it is sufficient to read the report by the Tyson group, an American company and a major player in the international meat market.
who announces having invested in Brazil in order to, I quote and this is in their report, use that country as a platform for exporting to Europe.
Other companies, such as Doo, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Numerous poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had borne the brunt of this operation.
Europe, without seeking to pursue its policy of relocation, by amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants, we must stop
Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the potential consequences for European agriculture resulting from the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, it is to be feared, and as a Member of Parliament representing an outermost region, I have experience with the banana accords. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur would inflict a serious blow on numerous European agricultural sectors.
That is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
It is also to be feared that this agreement may further, perhaps excessively, orient Mercosur's agriculture toward a productivist model to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.
Therefore, a balance must be found to ensure that this agreement does not transform the continents of Latin America and Europe into superpowers essentially grounded in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would simply like to say that we may not have structured our agenda very well today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter the territory of Europe, products that do not respect either our social standards or our environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be for naught.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a situation of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints.
to our farmers, on the grounds that it is necessary to protect consumers and, conversely, allow products to enter our continent freely without respecting these standards.
The question underlying the negotiation with Mercosur is precisely that one.

The way in which events were initiated, regardless of what we are told regarding the Parliament's thorough briefing and the proceedings occurring with utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that unfolds while parallel negotiations continue at the WTO.
In the name of coherence, consumer protection, and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, José Bové, to commend the Commissioner, and then Mr. Deß’s intervention, which preceded mine, regarding the objectives of this report.

I believe it is very important that we keep in mind that, in the debate we are having, we have to address a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices
They increase rapidly at the distribution level, but when prices decrease at the production level, there is no such repercussion for consumers.
There is indeed an organizational issue within the sector, and there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is termed added value within the sector.

I believe that José Bové’s report, on several points, offers perspectives that should be highlighted, and on this, I am genuinely addressing the Commission in an attempt to escape this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the field and the balance of power within it.
What proposals do we put forward to ensure that producers, when grouped together and organized, have greater influence within the sector to negotiate?
That is the question you raised, Mr. Commissioner, concerning cross-sectoral partnerships, but it is also a question posed on the basis of the contractual framework that will be established.
I contend, and it is in the report that this contractual basis has a European framework.
One cannot allow each country to resolve this issue.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposition, an inextricable path for me.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency.
On that matter, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers of price developments.
Indeed, I support the proposals that are being made, and I hope, as Mr. Desch said, that there will be a majority for
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I wanted today to commend this debate, which once again underscores the need for the Union to recognize and value its regional diversity.
In these years of negotiating the new framework programmes 2014, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the center of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a collection of exceptional measures.
We require a horizontal approach.
We must establish the instruments capable of fostering a synergistic coexistence of all areas of Community action in order to strengthen their added value.
Furthermore, as representative of the outermost regions and territories, I eagerly await the Union’s new strategy for the OCTs that the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first I align myself with my colleague's position regarding the Council’s absence from this parliamentary meeting.
I find that a little remiss on the part of the Council, and I want to say that as well.
As the next summit on October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must unequivocally and resolutely seek to advance together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at this same time, we were already busy, in this very chamber, urging Europe to do everything possible to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We observed that the outcome did not meet our expectations or our ambitions.
So, the concerns, a year later, remain the same, if anything even more pronounced.

To enable us today to constrain or persuade our partners, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, demonstrating, for instance, that we are providing the means to honor our commitments to Southern countries.
For this, the establishment of innovative financing and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy’s speech at the UN becomes a necessary certainty.
Therefore, for example, the implementation of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, far more than a threat ultimately, and a means of protecting our jobs and businesses, particularly to better navigate the post-crisis period.

Madam President, for me, the need to revalue family leave is not something that requires proof. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is an advancement, a benefit, and one should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two kinds: the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families adrift for decades; and the legal shortcomings of the report, as the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are irreconcilable.
Let us consider adoption leave, which appears in the text on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to biological mothers.
I am, in fact, the small additional package that Mme Morin mentioned, to be added to the Estrela report.

Mr. President, if the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the workforce, adoptive mothers who have become mothers in the same way as others are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
These are mothers like any other, fully so, who happen to adopt a child of more or less twelve months; indeed, there’s no discrimination, please note, as they appear in the text.
Regarding adoption, therefore, I regret that the text has been so little explored.
It was not even informed by the Ramboll impact study.
All of this is not well-developed, which is clearly a significant weakness.

Nevertheless, despite these caveats, I will support Ms. Estrela’s report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parental responsibilities in a society of

He is increasingly disengaged regarding the education of his young, but moreover, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, I would like to speak and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed the 2011 budget with the constraints we know, namely those of a profound crisis that Europe is undergoing, with national public deficits, which can lead to two hypotheses.
Do these national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or must these deficits at the national level give a new direction and renewed impetus at the European level?
That is where the question lies.
I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, above all, to try to think, when discussing a budgetary revision, when we begin to talk about budgetary perspectives for after 2013, of not
She cannot remain wholly steeped in the context of the crisis, unless she tells me and tells all the citizens of Europe that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire challenge lies in managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but also in preparing for the crisis's exit.
It is there that the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to emerge from the crisis—and Joseph Daul stated this immediately—unless the European budget, because it is European, is capable of providing us with the means to regain what we currently lack in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

That is the challenge, and it is by that measure that the budget should be discussed, rather than, as we too often do, constantly integrating the question of the crisis, the question of deficits. And on that point, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a reform of the treaties without even having discussed anything at all with Mr. Van Rompuy to sanction all states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

That's where we stand today at the Council level, while Parliament is asking for only one thing, and particularly of the Commission, that is to decide to launch the European project, and this is happening through the budget.
You have noted a number of points on which we are entirely in agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Obviously, we need to find together a capacity to have a much more flexible budget, because these are necessities; it is the responsiveness of Europe that is at stake.
This also, of course, involves setting priorities and ensuring the efficient allocation of the European budget.
We shall all agree on this, all agree—it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need a timeline, that we must collectively set goals, Commissioner. It cannot remain mere words, mere commitments, mere

These are texts that are, incidentally, very interesting and which I share almost entirely, but now it will be necessary to get down to specifics, and in particular, on a crucial issue around which we revolve: own resources.
How do we secure our own resources for tomorrow for Europe—not for Europe itself, but for all European citizens—and rediscover together the path to growth, and an even stronger path for Europe?
It falls to you, Commissioner.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by previous speakers regarding European economic governance, on the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the Stability and Growth Pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly cite two challenges facing our nations and facing G20 members that must be addressed within, in my opinion, the framework of the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of currency wars and that of commodity price volatility.
I believe that on these two subjects—which represent genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet—the Union

The European Commission is managing to organize itself, to establish common positions, and to provide itself with the means to speak with a single voice at upcoming G20 summits, in Seoul and those that follow, and more broadly on the world stage.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposal it contains.
Therefore, this also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only applaud this.
Furthermore, the Greek crisis revealed the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note on this point of Mr. Feio's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, and particularly its sanctions.
It is indispensable if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe the report clearly demonstrates the stakes involved in the marine environment in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological resources, and research combined with climate change.
It is a considerable development potential that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, for the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also notes, rightly so, that the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power and that its outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In light of such an observation, it therefore falls to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a comprehensive maritime policy.
If it is not the world’s foremost maritime power doing it, who else will?
However, it must be acknowledged that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a leadership position in global politics.
Finally, while the overseas regions possess a recognized strategic position, given their presence in all the oceans, it would have been possible to reduce them.
It would have been judicious to have them play a major role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not retained by the report, and I regret this, Mr. President.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement raises questions in the United States as well, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Furthermore, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
They contend that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the U.S. Constitution.
As the European Parliament prepares, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, the latter continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to have from our American interlocutors a very clear response concerning two points: can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their view, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already lacking the participation of China, India, and Brazil, and which would not be implemented by the United States, would greatly lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult delivery of the directive on alternative investment funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether or not they are based in the European Union.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but this truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is of a satisfactory nature.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gozes, who, after this particularly painful process for him, deserves a substantial period of leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the question of the treatment of third countries must still be observed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks, notably, to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore speak, to a greater or lesser extent, of a level playing field.

However, during the transitional period, non-European entities will benefit from the national placement regime, whereas funds and managers of the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.

The situation differs in markets located outside the European Union, where European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for funds from third countries.
It would therefore be considerably more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they will be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was, in part, inevitable.

Regarding depositaries, please be aware that we will also make this activity more stringent, particularly due to the new responsibilities that will burden them, and their increased cost should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to demonstrate my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is far from trivial; its implementation, which is necessary, will also entail difficulties of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, particularly at the beginning of the 21st century, patients require appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and to strictly adhere to the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposed revisions to the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical firms, which appears to us as nonsensical in terms of responding to patients’ actual needs.
This operation offers no benefit either to citizens or to Member States.
It signified, on the contrary, additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a motion to reject these texts, thereby requesting that the Commission reconsider its position.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schilter from the Green Group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr. Feischner, whom I commend, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission’s proposals.

Concurrently, we had submitted some sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patient access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled greater emphasis to be placed on patients’ rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, and the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has managed to counteract the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse that healthcare professionals be exploited to distribute to their patients brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical firms, without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly in the area of vaccination.
Information cannot freely come from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant, and indeed, and I conclude, what happened with mediator drugs demonstrates how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of equilibrium, as we have sought it with this draft report,

Mr. President, Madam the Commissioner, Madam the Minister, the Union and realism will be elaborated—at least, that is my wish—during tomorrow’s vote on our resolution concerning this sixteenth conference of the parties on climate change.

I hope that our designated commissioner will be able to champion the pragmatic objectives we will need to achieve collectively, but also defend the essential conditions stipulated by Europe, which is associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness held by our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of an insufficiently protected intellectual property will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for that reason, undervalue our current and future knowledge, even in this essential fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methodologies for emissions calculations, as well as data verification and publication, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standards, appears to be a perfectly legitimate request and not a bargaining tool.
Finally, more controversially—as my colleague raised earlier—the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all too well aware, with regret, that the true power of negotiation is not held by the European Parliament.

But the desire of numerous Members of the European Parliament, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference should be encouraged and not overlooked, as we may have felt on the final day.
If Europe wishes to be strong within international dialogues, it must be so for all these legislators.
Madam President, the European Union frequently presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
She is also despairing of not seeing these agreements signed as soon as possible.
But the question that engages us is to understand why these countries do not rush to sign agreements that would be so beneficial to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge regarding the quality of these agreements and, as long as these differences in assessment persist, ACP countries will hesitate to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
They wish to discuss development strategy, while Europe frequently responds with market liberalization.
It is this listening that is incumbent upon the ACP–EU Parliamentary Assembly.
I believe that other European bodies should proceed in the same manner if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly among the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the objective is their simple departure from this region—a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is essential to a certain equilibrium.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner to many countries in this region, has a responsibility to express strong indignation in light of the situation.
Discriminations, whatever their form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region until the most fundamental human rights, such as freedom of religion, are respected.
Dear colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently underway in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country’s Constitutional Council to call into question, in violation of the electoral code, the results of elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union–ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the COAS, and soon certainly the European Parliament are calling for respect for the official proclamation.
The results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the independent electoral commission—which, I recall, is an entity validated by the UN—
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for halting any escalation of tensions within the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire—something that must, of course, be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I also wanted to thank our four rapporteurs, who have performed remarkable work and have brought a significant added value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we, at the PPE, are preparing to vote on with enthusiasm represents a significant advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.

Let us not be deceived; this instrument can genuinely transform the European political landscape, provided that it is used with both responsibility and boldness, I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
It can contribute to bringing European citizens directly into the European political debate.

It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women who are citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together, and gather on genuinely European subjects.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to swiftly adopt implementing measures where necessary, let us not disappoint our citizens; this concerns the strengthening of European democracy.
Mr. President, I too, like many of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians worldwide, particularly Christians in the East.
No one needs to recall the horrific acts recently committed.
I would like to reiterate, with utmost solemnity, that defending Christians in the East, as everywhere in the world, advocating for religious freedom, the diversity of religions...

This belief is to advocate for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, values we are all convinced of here, universal values.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to move from words to action.
I therefore earnestly call upon the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the foreign ministers.
Implement precise measures, establish a specific, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam the High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
Allowing a lawless zone to establish itself at the gates of Europe is a danger that we must firmly and without delay confront.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
It is my turn to express my regret over the loss of human lives and the hostage-taking, and to express my concern for European nationals present there.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all forms of trafficking originating from the Sahel.
Alternatively, drug, arms, and human traffickers are now circumventing Morocco, passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands and onward to the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to act to assist these states in ending these threats.
The security of Europe is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I urge the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
That is what has been said, but I join in the expressions of sympathy and support already offered to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedoms.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, it has been said, has been noticeable for its lack of reaction, must indeed stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian people to help them successfully implement their countries’ openness to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in initiating a peaceful transition, preparing for the organization of upcoming elections, securing freedom, and enabling the Tunisian people to find prosperity through development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

To conclude, I will say that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge, as the Jasmine Revolution triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy toward these countries.
However, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Sir Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly reminded you.

At a time when Europe is questioning a common strategy for its supply of raw materials and, in particular, rare earth elements, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection channels, addressing the issue of leakage or illegal export of these materials, and increasing our collection targets must also be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the principal actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we wish to implement effective legislation.
To that end, my dear Carl Heinz, ecofootprinting, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but the citizen cannot be absolved of responsibility regarding the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be active participants, not mere spectators, in European environmental policy.
Madam President, Mr. President, Commissioner, I would first like to echo Ms. McGuinness’s remark regarding the essential link between food and agriculture.
The subject that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that this can have for a number of populations worldwide, but also in Europe.
I would first like to attempt to share an observation.

The tendency toward increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials is, in my view, a long-term trend that will endure for three essential reasons: global demographic evolution and the increase
Secondly, we have entered, with climate change, a period of climatic hazards that present a problem, whether it be drought or flooding. Third point, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
Tension on agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
It is on that subject that we must also address it, if we want to resolve the agricultural and food issues.

To that end, what the commissioner says is important: there are two elements. Yes, there needs to be transparency regarding inventories, but there also needs to be a public inventory policy in Europe and inventory management on a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

Secondly, there must be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volumes to become disconnected from the physical quantities being traded on those markets.
We cannot accept that, regarding food, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this can have, since it concerns the world’s food and humanity. I conclude for
Because this leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe’s commitment to being a global food and agricultural actor.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, worldwide—and Europe is an actor in this—we reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, agricultural commodity prices are soaring on global markets.
We are only 3 points shy of the 2008 level.
The decline in production in certain traditional export zones due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for biofuel production, and speculation

Financial institutions that inadvertently experienced upward effects are responsible for this situation, as demonstrated by the reports of the IMF, the French authorities, and as stated by the Commission as well.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely impacting the 1.2 billion inhabitants worldwide living below 1 dollar and
Since October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Just two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to adopt measures similar to those passed in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial entities in agricultural commodity markets.
It represents the first step in curbing speculators’ appetites.
The impact is dramatic for European livestock farmers as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are going bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne; today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals; it would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stockpiles in grain-producing countries to make them immediately available to livestock farmers at subsidized prices.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to breeders based on the evolution of feed costs for livestock.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a portion of the subsidies intended to support cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there’s a caveat.
The 2009 influenza outbreak in Chania demonstrated that each Member State responded independently, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictitious rapporteur on this case, I believe these observations needed to be made, but more importantly, we needed to go further, to be constructive, concrete for our citizens who, it must be said—and this is what I find most regrettable—have likely lost some confidence in public health messaging.

Ms. Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities, including, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and improved coordination with the
European health agencies, a clarification of the roles of European structures for health risk management, an evaluation of vaccination strategies and communication implemented in Member States.
It is therefore a good report; I congratulate the rapporteur, though it is, of course, essential that it not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, who retain the essential competencies in this area; it is therefore a genuine responsibility to embrace with regard to our citizens.
Mr. President, it is now my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination, on March 2nd last, of the Pakistani Minister for Christian Minority Affairs, Mr. Bati.
This act of terrorist violence follows numerous other killings of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, human rights defenders, and women’s rights advocates, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of individuals threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I think, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Ms. Sherry Rehmann.
I also wanted, once again, vigorously to request all competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations concerning

I would like to prepare the future cooperation agreements, notably the cooperation agreement between the Union and Pakistan, including a clause on respect for freedom of religion and respect for human rights.
Mr. President, for the record, with the crisis and the bursting of the property and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit, the cumulative budgetary balance of central, local, and particularly social security administrations, was estimated at 32% of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can scarcely refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Stability Financial Fund, it will have to comply with obligations of a social and fiscal nature, even though these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I will say that in the case of fever, it is pointless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without seeking to treat the underlying cause.
Should these funds be allocated, it falls to that State to undertake a fiscal consolidation in order to bridge its excessive deficit and rectify its prior errors.
This austerity plan is projected to increase GDP by 10 over the next four years.

Just as an individual lender, without intruding upon their life and private management, would condition a personal loan on a solvency guarantee, so too the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is in this way that, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency necessitates a reduction of the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without excusing itself from fiscal measures.
It falls to Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity that would allow, for example, the dangerously imposing of a European minimum wage, but a protection of the stability of the Eurozone through a mutual guarantee process.

It is, of course, appropriate to assist Ireland as are other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, particularly the price of seeing a state incapable of repaying its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have just said, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and ineffectiveness of European airspace.
And each of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
Five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without a viable alternative means of transportation.
A year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, relating to volcanic ash, is indeed scheduled for April 13th and 14th, coordinated by Eurocontrol, ICAO, and IATA, but it is essential that EASA assume genuine leadership for the coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as we saw last April, can nevertheless be contradictory and can lead each Member State to make decisions concerning the closure of their airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the AESA’s role is essential for proposing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as for ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the information provided to the VAC, the AESA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data, closely associating Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all concerned stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, with ESA, to present concrete proposals rapidly that will be fully integrated into the realization of the European single sky.
Madam President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
It is not a revolution; we cannot say that everything was bad before and that everything is perfect now.
Nevertheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.

The main concerns, in my opinion, relate to improved regulation of distance selling, and particularly online sales, and this is addressed in Chapter 3, as it is necessary to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful; it broadens consumer choice, allows them to obtain the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and craftspeople to find new markets.

To progress in this field, it was necessary to do so in a truly European manner, that is to say, on a few highly targeted points, to establish a complete harmonization of everyone’s rights and obligations.
Very concretely, an Italian customer purchasing from a Belgian or German website needed to know that, from now on, they would benefit from the same rights, the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that their withdrawal period will extend to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means he will immediately know the total amount he has to pay, without fear of an unpleasant surprise afterward.
This means that, with a double click, it will correctly verify its order.
Naturally, all of this will disrupt established practices.
In many states, there are nuances in national law that each is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes they are not even to be found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify these habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let us be clear, this text will still need to be improved, and we will need to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
I appreciated the overtures that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all political groups.
Consumer confidence in the Union’s internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point 7, following the first paragraph, a preliminary assessment shall ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the freedom of the individual.
Freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to demonstrate peacefully, to listen to and consider the legitimate demands of protesters, and to ensure their safety.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the Open Skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only one stage—a stage that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the Commission itself have highlighted this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits accrued since 2008.

Allow me then to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, because pilots, among whom I count myself, find themselves facing a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so at the expense of 90 general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some holding a single U.S. license and to the detriment, and this is important, of businesses and jobs linked to this activity.
Mr. President, I wish to draw your attention to this project, which lacks any security rationale.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among holders of an American license.

The basic regulatory text 216’s objectives allow for the anticipation of license recognition and equivalence, the interest of which would not seem to warrant waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed to 2014.
