Thus, I propose an exceptionally open invitation to join me, even to accompany me when I occasionally visit Parliament piloting myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is entirely safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or reinforce certain points that have already been made.

But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, the problems that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No Member State should find itself alone facing the challenges that confront it and that, in my view, confront the entire European Union.
It is therefore truly to the capacity of the European Union to organize itself and to face challenges collectively, in a spirit of solidarity, that I call upon.
I believe the time has truly come now to lay the groundwork for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
More than a year ago, a European asylum and immigration pact was adopted.
The time has come now, I think, to delineate it in a very concrete manner.
We have, of course, Madam Commissioner, heard a number of recommendations that you were making.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly emphasize several of these proposals.
Yes, it is essential to bolster the resources of the Frontex agency.

Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the human resources, material resources, and financial resources of the Frontex agency, and to enable it to more substantially support the Hermes and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed, additional resources for Member States that are facing, I would say, first and foremost, the intensified migratory flow that we are experiencing today.
It will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, it is necessary to forge closer relationships of cooperation with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, to support them, of course, to assist them, to find instruments.
Madame the Commissioner was, I believe, mentioning that she went to Tunisia to discuss the mobility partnerships.
Yes, these instruments must be strengthened in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a spirit of precision and concreteness.

Mr. President, Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here concerning your communication relate to the place of public services, services of general economic interest, within the single market, and their legislative transposition.
We have arrived at a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal 25, and we ask you to go beyond a mere

communication that would fail to meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders, users, and all parties involved in public services, and that would also fall short of the objectives you yourselves define.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message regarding public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework—regulation or directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with its legal foundations.
It is now up to you to translate them into legislative proposals.
I believe the Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.
Mr. President, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their monumental work on this discharge, and I also welcome the Council’s presence for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not simply a matter of economics.

I am speaking today in this hemicycle on the occasion of the debate on discharge 2009, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the budgetary control committee as a windfall, a simple means of making savings.
The question of parliamentary spending also interests me.
On that subject, I propose holding the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, which would allow us to better utilize our Parliament building in Strasbourg.
Since we want to make savings, I propose other measures, for example, eliminating Friday absenteeism for our colleagues, as well as eliminating absenteeism allowances for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that one is not obliged to give a handout to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate a significant issue that extends beyond the scope of budgetary oversight, even though I commend the important work of Ville, our rapporteur, regarding this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also wish that we would rationalize and cleanse the system of compensation for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it particularly moral, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader should be reimbursed in cash, in specie, on the day of the visit, without any work being done, without any check of what the group has spent.
Occasionally, the allocated sum—I bring this to your attention—exceeds the amount of actual expenditures.

It would be logical for groups to send a quotation in advance to the visits service, to receive an account from the Parliament on expenditures, and that to a bank account, and for the balance to be paid upon presentation of invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. I thank you.
Madam President, I address the Commission, my colleagues, and I greet the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the 2011 management of the Schengen Area.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; rather, it is a space that has continuously expanded in recent years and now comprises twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
As all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it encompasses today, a reality that is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that the proposals of the Italian and French governments, and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration, should be read.
Mutual trust among the States Parties to the Schengen Area is, of course, the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust rests on reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
It must therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control over these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures will fully respect the spirit of Schengen, to the extent that these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not on an intergovernmental basis.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the entirety of the long-term measures considered within the framework of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide for greater solidarity—I conclude on this point—to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a shortcoming of the Schengen acquis.
Madam President, within just a few weeks, migrants from countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant proportion of annual immigration to France.
This acquisition is not static, but must instead evolve.

I hope that these proposals will be swiftly adopted, so as to ensure the most expeditious possible management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, to safeguard the security of our shared external borders. Thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally taken sanctions against Syria.
But, unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding challenging the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of resolve and clarity is, of course, interpreted by protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as leniency that allows them to intensify the struggle.
Repression so cruel that one cannot even imagine, at the same moment, Syria being elected to sit on the UN Human Rights Council.
of the United Nations, whereas even today, Syrian authorities are denying the UN observers access to the city of Dehra, the site of terrible violence perpetrated against defenseless civilians.

The assassination at the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brute force against its people, in disregard, precisely, of the values that the Human Rights Council must safeguard.
Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avoid such a disaster?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has produced a work of exquisite craftsmanship on this report – and believe me, it was very complex.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders, and they have succeeded.
Whether concerning police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, and the control of air, maritime, or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only observe this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now in a position to implement this Schengen acquis in both technical and personnel terms.
Furthermore, if no obstacle today prevents this expansion of the Schengen Area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly followed, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know, mutual trust among Schengen states rests on the full compliance by those states with their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations, it creates air leaks, and the entire system becomes faulty.
I sincerely hope that an agreement will be reached at the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circle formed by the Schengen States.
And we will all, within this chamber, measure the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, bravo to Mr. Coelho for his report, Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport systems more modern.
All European institutions have strongly supported this objective, including nearly all Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have endeavored to strip the new Eurovignette Directive proposal of its substance and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the persistence of our rapporteur—and I would like to acknowledge Saeed El Khadraoui here—thanks to his persistence and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Therefore, it is true that this text is considerably less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will, for the first time, put the "polluter pays" principle into practice and internalize external costs of transportation, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

To ensure this eurovignette is not merely a tax but effectively contributes to the improvement of transportation in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the funds collected in the modernization of transport modes.
Parliament also succeeded in securing tangible progress regarding the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

To remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us in the second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I agree that alongside liberty and fraternity, there should be equality for farmers and for the countries that have integrated, for the countries rejoining from the East.
Yes, I concur with you.
I believe we have made a significant stride with this report.
It wasn’t easy initially, and we were rather in a confrontational posture, but we arrived at a consensus, and that's what matters most.
This consensus safeguards the overarching project, and I believe that is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Mercedes, and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity, simultaneously, of equality, justice, and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe that is important.

We have stated very clearly and we have confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which are essential for the quality and biodiversity of territories.
I believe that was also fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now, it will be necessary to implement this; it is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
It is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, the concern we have is that, indeed, there are threats to the budget.
It will be necessary to respond to it clearly.

Now, what we are anticipating is that we move into the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and broad intentions, it is within the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are going, and that is what we are, of course, anticipating now.
I would still like to conclude by voicing my outrage at Germany’s stance, which has resulted in a reduction of five [units] in food aid for the poorest in Europe.
It was within the EU’s agricultural policy budget.
I want us to rediscover the means of helping the most vulnerable. There are 80 million European citizens who do not eat properly.
Mr. President, while the European Parliament can indeed boast of some notable advances in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to exercise humility, for we are dancing on the edge of an abyss.
Let us be acutely aware of two things.
The first point is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
While, ordinarily, we are so quick to respond to all sorts of events with resolutions worldwide, this existential crisis seems to leave us without recourse.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, to European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I desire, these six directives or regulations, we will certainly enable the Eurozone to take a step forward.
No further steps toward a discipline that has so long eluded us, a step—I say, nothing more—that will demonstrate its usefulness in the future.
But one need only observe the heated debates surrounding the overturned qualified majority to gauge the distance we still have to travel, when it should be a matter of automatic rules and sanctions.
The mechanism of the reverse qualified majority continues to act on some like a scarecrow.
We must, however, remain steadfast on the principle.
On a purely political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management in the face of all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are mutually exclusive.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets like responsible heads of households, but not through stimulus spending. It is a short-term palliative, but never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks unfold as crucial, today it concerns refounding an economic Union.
This morning, we voted on a very important text for the progress of consumer protection in Europe, following three years of work.
He rightly focuses on online purchases that may, in twenty years, represent 25% of all commerce in Europe, which is quite considerable.
These discussions will be notably transnational.
They will enable consumers to broaden their choices and also to pay significantly less.
This represents a genuine advancement.
For SMEs, for all artisans, it is also a very important possibility for expanding their markets.

Among the key advancements, I would simply like to cite two: the cancellation period, which extends to fourteen days, and the recapitulation of all information and the total price to be paid before pressing the final button that places the order.

And finally, I am proud, within the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but the entire group of our colleagues, voted unanimously across all political groups, because, on such a subject, it was not controversy that we needed, but obviously consensus.
It was we who obtained it.

Madam President, Commissioners, I would first like to commend our colleague Carlos Coelho’s efforts on this very difficult file, which requires considerable expertise, a great deal of work, and thorough knowledge of the matter.
The control of our common territory and of our European borders is one of the most important challenges we must address, and technological tools are more than ever at the service of this challenge.
Indeed, over recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some describe as a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the years to come.
The SIS, VIS, and EURODAC are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring sound operational management of these databases is therefore a critical matter to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is, of course, highly delicate, and Carlos Cuello faced numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles. Nevertheless, he managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all interested parties.
The establishment of this network agency appears, indeed, to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.
It will enable improved management of existing information systems, offer greater synergy between these databases, and furthermore allow for the integration of instruments adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this case was the location of the agency – where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have offered to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, the operational management and administration of which it has ensured since 1995; it therefore possesses total technical mastery of it.
Following the conclusions of the December 2003 European Council, which prioritized the new Member States, Estonia also wished to receive the seat of this future agency.

Mr. President, it seems to me that the agreement reached is very good. A sort of division of responsibilities – I conclude, Madam President – has taken place by transferring the agency’s headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and exploitation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.

The cost-effectiveness ratio is very balanced, and this compromise solution does not undermine centralized IT systems management. Madam President, I am very pleased to have spoken with you about this report.
Mr. President, the transversal social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon guarantee social rights in a binding manner, and in particular, the right to access essential services.
It is time to demonstrate to European citizens that the social Europe is underway.

Therefore, it is necessary to give our social acquisitions the full place they deserve within Community law, by recognizing the specificity of Social Service Enterprises (SSE) with regard to competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local base and are underpinned by actors within the social economy.

Mr. De Rossa’s report provides an opportunity to reaffirm the simple yet powerful and meaningful principles of equality, universality, and access to collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it was time to move to specifics.
Yes, it is time to move to the concrete, so I propose, within this debate, to genuinely support a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green group.
Mr. President, discussions concerning GMOs must imperatively be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientific and legal alike.
Legally, member states wishing to restrict or prohibit GMOs within their territory required arguments as varied as they were robust.
The rapporteur has broadened the range of possible approaches, but it remains weak nonetheless.
I don’t know.
This foundational scientific dossier must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the scientific evaluations of the EFSA, which have consistently been positive regarding GMOs, in contrast to national scientific evaluations.

To restore confidence, shouldn't we, Commissioner, first and foremost simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide considerable scientific safeguards, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council’s recommendations from October 2008 remained unimplemented?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I wish to thank our colleague Simon Busuttil for the remarkable work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate them for it.
This report outlines an agency with tenfold resources, more aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the necessity of closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a robust agency.
Frontex finally obtains the resources to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly effective.
New tasks are also assigned to him, such as the organization of voluntary returns and the processing of personal data so that we can combat transnational crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex’s field of competence empowers us to consider and address migration issues through a holistic approach and to avoid being confined to a purely mechanical management of borders.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, notably Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is ensured by the proposal to establish a consultative council within the Agency.

I can only commend this comprehensive proposal, which takes a step forward towards sound and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and ongoing; I thank you for it.

Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and the remarks of my colleagues, sometimes critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a wonderful opportunity to discuss the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
However, it is the Commission, having a direct, sometimes physical, connection with the citizen, that can witness our debates firsthand.
She possesses undeniable legitimacy within Parliament, as well as extensive expertise, owing to her direct relationship with the citizenry.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates despite the painful cases that are frequently addressed.
This Commission embodies the Europe it ought to be, attentive to the concerns of its citizens and united in finding and protecting solutions for them.
Unfortunately, avenues for action and means of influence remain limited, particularly concerning the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost complete.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as the rights of the family or the rights of the child in the event of divorce.
We will, in fact, be conducting a mission on this subject in November.
I also regret that the national authorities do not always expedite the provision of all the necessary information to us.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if it could sometimes go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are conducting with the European Ombudsman.
I now call upon citizens to continue to solicit us through petitions as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to underscore its extreme urgency.
Let us first observe that what was a priority yesterday remains so, even more emphatically, today.

The absence of a definition and of reliable statistical indicators on precariousness should not prevent us from noting that the crisis has seen the number of people living below the poverty threshold rise, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million, estimated therefore in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, requested that Member States put an end to the problem of tax shopping schemes by 2015.
Today, we are ourselves somewhat closer to our objective.
Did the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly enable Member States to concretely address this widespread precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely question this, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I wish to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy to address homelessness, because, of course, there is poverty and a lack of housing, certainly, but there are also familial issues, health concerns, various dependencies, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious yet tailored approach is needed, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their backgrounds, and their life disruption.
It is a right, at the very least fundamental, from which many of the most vulnerable individuals are deprived.
Madam President, these past years, everyone has said it, the European Union has been struck by unprecedented disasters, and the cities here would take the entirety of the debate.
I will still mention the Azed F explosion, the tenth anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened response at the European level, as proposed in Ms. Gardini’s report, represents a genuine opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been striving to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and the time has come to act together and no longer wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before drawing lessons from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent further tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier, you stated that risks must be anticipated.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing from funding the GMES satellite observation program, which is universally recognized as an essential tool for preventing and coordinating responses to disasters.
I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programs that give Europe an undeniable added value.
Well, I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her very good report.
I hope that we will adopt it, thereby paving the way for European solidarity at the service of the citizen. I thank you.
Mr. President, Commissioner, Minister, the number of people living in poverty and unemployed individuals continues to increase within the European Union.
Over 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is critical.
Today, six Member States wish to terminate the food aid program without any replacement solution: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a ruling from the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July, at the initiative of our Green Group, and you put forward pertinent proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot reduce the food aid budget by a factor of four.
The urgency is real.
If nothing is done by the end of the year, food banks will be short over €300 million, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to fill this shortfall.
It is therefore a genuine question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow a minority of irresponsible governments to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is fundamentally a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our methods of production in order to bring food production closer to populations, particularly the most vulnerable, who are also entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans need food assistance.
The Council must regain its senses and allow those in need to access this vital assistance.
I would particularly like to address the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Does it take riots and famine in Europe to realize the pressing necessity of changing our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council knows how to find solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. Parliament delivered a strong message last time: human beings are more important than finance.
finance, it is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and will not fail to renew our call in a constructive manner.
Indeed, six Member States hold the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
Six Member States claiming to do no more and no less than legal formalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we fail to express our anger toward those who remain deaf to the cries of alarm raised by associations assisting the most vulnerable?

And we, the Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, do we desire an Europe where national self-interests dictate policy, paying scant regard to the citizens of States facing budgetary difficulties?
There is no question of renationalizing this support.

No, let us maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let us not abandon those who, in the immediate future, in 2012, rely on this assistance during a particularly difficult time of crisis.

Mr. President, Commissioner, I will not revisit the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe and, in particular, in Belgium, in Liège, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct layoffs and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a resident of Liège, I share the shock and distress of the 581 workers and their families who have been laid off.
But I also think of the severe restructurings announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons given are always the same: unfavorable prospects for the steel market in Europe, strong competition from imports from China, Korea.
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automobile market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Liège site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this, and despite a difficult 2010, the Belgian Arcelor Mittal steel group’s financial center generated a profit of €1.394 billion.
He paid zero euro in tax, representing a tax rate of zero.
It is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across multiple sites.
The closure of sites is, in the minds of these leaders, nothing more than an economic adjustment variable where human considerations are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You have spoken, Commissioner, of the regulations.
Shouldn't the Commission now develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

Six years ago already that our Parliament adopted a report concerning relocations, the corporate code of conduct, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do regarding this matter, and within what timeframe?
If we are to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
robust European framework to address relocations and restructurings, and to ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.
Finally, in the case of the Liège site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to compensate the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs sweeping workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational corporations that act.

without any social ethics, which carries out stock market layoffs and relocates in order to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and appease rating agencies, regardless of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last concerning the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, workers affected by the negative effects of restructurings.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure coherence between the FEMM's activities and the European Union's industrial policy, notably through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future FEM regulation include improvements so that the Fund does not produce the outcomes it generates today regarding multinational corporations, those random, moral effects, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Sir Commissioner, we can no longer examine the issues of structural funds and the adjustment for globalization fund separately without
without taking into account the restructuring strategies employed by companies that benefit from it, without examining the cost-benefit analysis of a policy – I repeat this clearly
Mr. President, the European Ombudsman conducts investigations into complaints directed against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with considerable skill.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate free movement—that of our businesses and our citizens—but it is also a formidable guarantee, particularly in the face of detractors of the Union who too often claim that the European Union is nothing more than an unaccountable bureaucratic machine.
It is clearly nonsensical; Europe is doing genuine work on itself, thanks notably to the European Mediators.
But allow me to relay an observation that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission finds itself under heavy criticism.
There are first the figures 65 and the actual number, not 12, of investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also representatives from numerous companies who come to see us to explain their misunderstanding of the Commission, of a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, concerning the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people find it suitable.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present on the petitions committee.
You are aware that the European Commission is giving us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member of Parliament’s questions or who take refuge in a jargon almost as skillfully as politicians do, presenting themselves to citizens advocating their cause.

I wanted therefore to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the Ombudsman lie Europeans relieved to be heard but disappointed by
This behavior of citizens negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions may create a feeling of revolt, incomprehension, and, ultimately, perhaps Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Mediator against institutions in general are heard; I thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union—such are the terms in which the subject of today is framed.
We, the PPE group, have given our support to the report by our colleague, Ms. McLaughlin, a report to whose development we contributed significantly, and we obviously support

This is the principal recommendation of this report for greater professional mobility, increased simplification, and enhanced efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer safety.
But it is in terms of the pathway to growth that the challenge of increased professional mobility arises.
Incidentally, the Forum for a Single Market, held in Krakow at the beginning of October, was not mistaken on this point.

who recalled that Member States must recognize the potential of the internal market to stimulate growth and job creation and must act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
The European Council of 23 October last also identified as a key priority for achieving smart, sustainable growth.

This concerns notably the implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Act for the Single Market, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, under which the recognition of professional qualifications.

We clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential inherent in the single market, our single market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore allow not only to ensure, if we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve it, the free movement of our fellow citizens within this market, but also, we hope, to acquire additional growth margins.
That is why we, notably—I want to emphasize a practical recommendation—we, the PPE, in particular, have provided our support for the implementation of a voluntary pre-positioning policy.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Cashmarck, for his excellent work.
I would like to state that it is important for the European Parliament to annually assess the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, insofar as
This assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 proved to be a productive year for the PPP, which met twice, as mentioned by previous speakers, in Spain and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, to exchange views in particular
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, and also on media freedom and independence and food security.
But in 2010, the PPE also sent its first election observation mission of this legislature.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission to Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assaride, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was a resounding success.
We were able to meet all the concerned political actors, and thanks to the delegation's dual ACP and European origin, we embodied a legitimacy distinct from European or African missions.

I therefore invite the PPE office to renew this experience, which allows for the practical application of solidarity and the privileged relationships that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his very interesting report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, it is a social crisis for our citizens.
Reducing the number of people in a precarious situation by 20 million by 2020 requires decisive measures involving all levels of public authority.

We must, more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and upon the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must ensure the sustainability and optimization of European funds, and in particular the current program of aid for the most vulnerable, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent individuals.
Poverty is a scourge to be combatted at the grassroots level, and the time has come to take action to enable the most vulnerable to escape their precarious situation.

And we must, as policymakers at the European, national, and local levels, take the necessary steps to ensure their non-discriminatory access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, and access to a first job, with a minimum income that may be indexed according to the poverty rate of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, and in poverty reduction, will enable us to implement a sustainable, intelligent, and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we desire and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms. Levin, for her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the development committee, I am pleased that the fisheries committee has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing at the global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires global solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing nations.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of States are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without accompanying measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capabilities.
Therefore, it is necessary to support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
Therefore, the Union must strengthen the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area with developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are enforced, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources they could derive from the economic activity of fishing.
Alternatively, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states receiving aid.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to curb this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to state that, largely thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power.
This represents a major asset for Europe as well; the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy concerning the sea, the oceans, and the seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, it will not be necessary, sufficient to undertake this major challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent, at the European level, to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly within the framework of international cooperation.
I also note that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Réunion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not address this matter, I seize this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this specific issue.
Madam President, I would first like to commend the Polish presidency, which has demonstrated dynamism and commitment.
Next week, at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the euro area, for the future of the Union.
They will also need to seriously address the recovery of growth.

That being said, we are well aware that today, financial stability has become the priority of priorities, and that the pressures and tensions exerted from outside the Eurozone, as well as within it, are undermining our credibility and eroding confidence.
To hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debt.
Financial stability has truly become the priority of priorities, it has become a pressing obligation for all.

Our democracies have, moreover, all embarked on very ambitious programs to consolidate their public finances and reduce their debt, but financial stability is also a prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
But who speaks of solidarity, who speaks of financial stability, budgetary discipline – because these go hand in hand, of course – must also speak of solidarity.
It seems to us important to ensure this twofold movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to undermine the responsibility of our democratic institutions.

Rather than contemplating recourse to a judicial mechanism to penalize in the event of budgetary deviations, I would suggest considering control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

To be entirely frank, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, and very frankly, even though I belong to the same political affiliation as he does, I am not, I would say, in a constant position to relay the statements of the French Minister for Foreign Affairs.
To be entirely frank once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Juppé to that effect.
I simply believe that France's current position is to constantly reaffirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that the safeguarding of the euro,

I want to speak of safeguarding this shared project and safeguarding the European Union. In this movement to preserve the euro, we must, of course, think of the future, think of the protection of younger generations, and the preservation of peace on our continent.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, tomorrow we will vote for the third time on the new development cooperation instrument.
the development, which foresees support measures in the banana sector for ACP exporting countries following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.
This assistance program has a budget of €190 million and is directed to ten ACP countries until 2013.
It is of crucial importance to our African and Caribbean partners, as the banana sector holds considerable economic and social weight in these countries.
If the entirety of the Parliament’s claims regarding the application of delegated acts have not been incorporated into this instrument, I deeply regret this.
Nevertheless, we did manage to achieve progress.
Indeed, the text outlines clear objectives and precise criteria for the allocation of resources to the Commission.
The Commission also issued a statement detailing the methodology employed.

Furthermore, we have a statement from the Council on the forthcoming multiannual financial framework clarifying that it will duly take into account the delegated acts in external assistance instruments after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, Parliament clarifies—and this point seems to me to be crucial—that this is in no way intended to set a precedent.

And I would like to tell you that I have just returned from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU JPA took place, and I believe I can say that our ACP partners are counting on us given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the deplorable consequences for our ACP partners if the ICD BAM were rejected.
The situation of certain farmers is dramatic; we can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I therefore count on your support for the text. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, our coordinator, Tissbergmann, is ultimately unable to be present this evening for personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis of this case.

The conciliation on this legislative package has been lengthy and arduous, and while the outcome regarding human rights instruments and the ICI+ is satisfactory, we remain far from achieving a resolution concerning the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise found on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on the same level as the Council on all programming decisions concerning the selection of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
For it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are at stake here.
The selection of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have its say.
By categorically refusing to recognize any power of oversight for Parliament and resorting to shameful blackmail, the Council has, once again, displayed a deplorable ideological retreat.
But Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the banana instrument.
It is the only way we have of showing the Council and the Commission that Parliament desires greater transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurd would dictate that we must wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers already provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.
Mr. President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that defense policy is fundamentally a national policy.
It addresses the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Capability sharing is nothing more than a loss of sovereignty. The single market for military equipment is a vast joke when some Member States believe that
The defense guarantees itself in Washington, prioritizes equipping itself with American matériel, Europe being incapable, in this area as in so many others, of imposing community preference.

Regarding the common security challenges faced by the Union’s member states, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, independently of any intervention from Brussels.

I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Mrs. Ashton would amount to acknowledging that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accepting that the Mercosur couple can impose a pure German Europe on twenty-seven peoples—a sheer mental aberration.

For thirty years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets are the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor, to the point of rendering most of our military equipment obsolete.

deficient or outdated, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, with each waiting on the neighbor or the presumed big brother American to make the efforts it is no longer willing to make itself.
But you are addressing the wrong person.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we can individually equip ourselves with the means necessary not only for our security and national interests, but also for the cooperation of those means in addressing common challenges.
An accumulation of weaknesses and deficiencies never constitutes a strength.

Mr. President, I wished to convey the support of the French delegation from the PPE group for the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Economic Governance in Europe and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let us not be mistaken.
This treaty represents a significant step toward greater economic and budgetary integration, toward greater financial stability.
Let us restate it here.
There can be no sustained recovery of growth and employment without sound public finances.
Of course, growth cannot be decreed; it is not a treaty that, by itself, can revive growth.
But a treaty, that is to say a set of rules and mutual commitments, can foster trust and accountability.

As the president of the socialist group saw fit to introduce partisan politics into this chamber and by making allusion to the forthcoming French presidential campaign, referencing the socialist candidate in that French presidential election, I wished to respond.
We, the PPE, consider the declarations of the French socialist candidate, who stated his desire to renegotiate the treaty concluded by
Renegotiate what and with whom.
These words are entirely irresponsible.
They pay little heed to the word of the French State, nor to the respect due to the commitments of the French State.

Madame Ashton, Madagascar, one of the world’s poorest countries, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading to presidential and legislative elections.
The intersection of this country is negative.
Under normal circumstances, our contribution approximates 50% of this country’s budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support for the ninth and tenth EDF tranches, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population suffers, and businesses established in Madagascar are sometimes compelled to contribute against their will.

While supporting your position, we wish you to exert all your influence with the SADC so that the legal and judicial impasse concerning the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements of the implementation of this roadmap.

I would appreciate your input on this matter, and I would also like to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar friendship group, which we have recently established in the European Parliament, is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defense of our Union’s values.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr. Iturguyès, for the quality of his work, for the lengthy period of negotiation he had to undertake, and for the patience he demonstrated.

We are finally arriving at the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring up to this hemicycle, to the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens.
Here is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Petitions concerning the environment are predominant, and waste constitutes a significant concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a social issue.
We consume in Tuva.
We are only now beginning to realize that what is not consumed is thrown away.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a wake-up call for Member States.
It is still unsettling to see that the states appear not to be mastering the situation.
Only six member states have transposed the Waste Directive, the Waste Framework Directive, on time.
The number of complaints received on the matter sometimes demonstrates a lack of transparency in the selection of landfill locations.
Finally, and most worryingly, organized crime appears to be doing as it pleases.
A market of 75 billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
It is necessary to increase sanctions against companies that leak public contracts to enrich themselves.
This report serves as a warning to the States, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of waste directives.
It is necessary to make this file visible, but also credible.
If no one plays along, we will continue to waste time and money in verification and counter-verification procedures that risk lasting for years.
Let us heed the petitioners’ message and halt this waste more swiftly.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he displayed before the Council and the Commission.
Despite this, I fear that what we have achieved does not allow for a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of that familiar illusion, the one recounted by children, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would graze on grass alongside sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mme Fischer Boel has done everything to ideologically dismantle dairy quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors, nonetheless, recognized the effectiveness of these dairy quotas.

Or, today, we are in a situation that will be even more dramatic, and we see what is currently happening in Denmark, where the most robust farms, with the increase in production, are all facing bankruptcy, with a 40% drop in land prices.
Is that what we want for the European level?
I say no; it is necessary to control production with the participation of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we uphold, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify personal data concerning them, as well as the right to lodge a judicial appeal in the event of a violation of their rights.
It is necessary to act to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a potential legal conflict detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, for we cannot absolve ourselves of our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this forum.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as establishing a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and therefore the personal data protection of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.
Mr. President, first of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits threatening the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion nor the rise in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is now urgent that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for Member States, within a growth perspective.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that emphasis should be placed on subjects such as diversity and inclusion, training, reskilling, microcredit, apprenticeships, and paid internships, among others.

Or, and Commissioner Andor recalled a moment ago, we have 23 million unemployed individuals in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros in European funds dedicated to employment that remain untapped.
We could practically make a 23 strategy out of it.
And that is not counting the €60 billion of cohesion funds that remain unallocated.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on flexicurity.
Let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with social incentives more advantageous than those linked to unemployment and active support for all socially responsible businesses.
We had poverty reduction targets to achieve by 2020, but we already know that they will not be met, lacking strong and adequate measures taken by Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be exercised fully, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy invested in enacting robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, undeniably, the cause of women owes much to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been repeatedly reaffirmed since in numerous treaties.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
Consequently, Europe has consistently pursued gender equality and the advancement of women with considerable initiative.
Little by little, progress has been made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, and directives have been implemented.
Here, within our Parliament itself, there has been for many years an extremely active and vigilant commission on women's rights and gender equality.
A European institute for gender equality has been established.
Programs are implemented, and financial resources are voted year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of the European Equal Treatment and Equal Pay Day, Equal Pay.
a European Equal Pay Day. Undeniable, therefore, that the legislative framework exists, and European will has been realized on numerous occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains ever relevant—the struggle for gender equality and, in particular, for equal pay.
There is consistently, on average, across all European Union countries, a salary gap of approximately
70 for equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, entirely unacceptable.
The Parliament’s Women’s Committee is currently working on a draft resolution calling on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on gender equality.
The treatment, which is one of the most concerning and central battles, at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of implementing quotas—quotas both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life—I come from a country, France, which adopted them long ago, it was
ten years, binding rules regarding quotas in political life, and more recently, about a year ago, a law for the establishment of quotas on the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
What is the assessment after several years of implementation in one case, and several months in the other, compelled as we are to note that things have shifted, that progress has been made?
Therefore, a necessary evil.
Quotas do have an effect.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken a significant step towards the establishment of quotas at the European level within the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this large public consultation aimed at gathering opinions on the actions to be implemented, and potentially legislative actions to be implemented.
On this matter, you will have my full and complete support.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two subjects, first the stakes of water management worldwide and in Europe.
an Europe, and then a question to the European Commission so that acts can allow us to respond to a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.
The stakes, as we know, are water—the defining issue of the twenty-first century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We understand the stakes, we understand the stakes in terms of management, we understand the stakes in terms of food security.
And, on the occasion of this forum, as our colleague Rivasi recalled, far too many purely commercial concerns are at the heart of the discussion that has unfolded in Marseille in recent days.
A question: why is there a lack of coherence between water management, water-related resources, and the Common Agricultural Policy because
Nothing in the reform of the CAP [Common Agricultural Policy] addresses this management, as our colleague Sarboud mentioned earlier.
Provide us with answers.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank the rapporteur and our assistants for the work accomplished.
This report now aptly lives up to its title, namely, removing obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a remarkable project, but it is too frequently observed that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Let us take the economic crisis as an example.
It has brought to light our weaknesses and allowed us to build more solidly the regulatory institutions of our single market.
For the European citizen, it’s the same.
The petitions committee, a veritable complaints bureau, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European citizens' initiative will complete this framework.
Despite all our policies that call for mobility, adherence to European values, and exchanges, there remain far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
A citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not go to the polls; it is a citizen who will not see the value that Europe represents in their daily life.
With my PPE colleagues, we have put forward a great many proposals, the most numerous, and I wish to thank them for this.
It is a report that should engender a sense of belonging and European identity, which we must recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has put forward twenty-five very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are paramount for restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, moving, children's rights, employment, health, and safety.
Citizen participation, healthcare abroad, town twinning, minority rights, etc. We still struggle to fully leverage the opportunities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are its conduits here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must demonstrate to citizens that with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
Mr. President, I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for influencing behavior.

I believe that energy consumption should align with a price signal for the consumer and, above all, I think that, to avoid any distortion on the internal market, we must attempt to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportional taxation across different levels of energy products therefore appears to me to be a necessity.
In the case at hand, for example, this would allow us to put an end to diesel tourism, which we are currently witnessing and which is not an acceptable situation.
I therefore share the philosophy underpinning the Commission's directive revision proposal.

Nevertheless, if we are to achieve our objectives in terms of CO2 emission reduction or energy efficiency, it is also essential that our collective decisions do not penalize citizens or sectors particularly vulnerable to pollution.

Price volatility in global markets, and I'm thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, certainly differentiated according to each Member State's level of taxation, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.
The question is who, in the final, will have to bear this price increase?
Do real, practical, and accessible alternatives for consumers truly exist?
As a fictional rapporteur on the environment committee, I support an ambitious yet, above all, sustainable position for everyone.

I therefore advocate for greater progressivity and the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality by 2030, subject to a new impact study, updating that upon which the Commission relies, which was nonetheless carried out five years ago.

A month earlier, right here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe resulting from the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational corporation present in nine European member states and which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to a subdued demand for steel.
Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium, in Luxembourg, and the idling of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6,000 direct jobs would be threatened for the year 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices, such as stop-and-go operations—a practice that should be more effectively regulated—the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change demands extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced the need to undertake, in light of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for the responsible management of restructurings with social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple: six months later, where do we stand?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I first wish to refute the unfounded allegations concerning the circulation in France of 500 to one million fraudulent biometric passports that purportedly circulate within our country.
France takes the risks of identity document fraud very seriously.
She does not take offenses in this area lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is a criminal offense punishable by one year of imprisonment and a fine of 15 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, which has enabled prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud reference point is designated.
Furthermore, the security measures for the issuance of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil registry data provided may be verified between administrative services, as far as possible through electronic means, in order to limit the risk of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the proof-of-address justification trap.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path toward increased security of proof of address documents with the incorporation of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted during previous title requests, and potential authentication of supporting documents.

The security of title issuance is further ensured by the applicant’s dual appearance, first at the time of application submission and subsequently for title collection, as well as the capture of two biometric fingerprints.
And that is without mentioning the enhanced verification procedures for the renewal of lost and stolen titles, for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, and notably Interpol, to conclude, Mr. President, that I am nearing completion of the passports issued, lost, or stolen, so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
Dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, an observation: our citizens increasingly wish to find and consume food produced locally and seasonally, for reasons of health and quality, among others.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and rapidly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as the maintenance of local abattoirs, which, while ensuring rigorous sanitary controls, facilitate the development of local short circuits and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will allow farmers to retain a larger portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to encourage and facilitate direct sales within the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points that allow local consumers access to a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery systems, such as AMAPs in France, which enable nearly 3 farmers to supply 60 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add further criteria concerning, in particular, the size of the holding, the volume of production, or the traditional nature of the product to define local agriculture.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am pleased that this corrective budget concerning the financing of ITER, which has been voted, enjoyed a broad majority in the Budget Committee on March 29th last.
By financing this additional cost, we avoid dismissing a strategically fundamental research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven Euratom community partners has questioned their overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work, and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Kadaraš.
From 2015 through 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and the machine assembly could mobilize up to 4 people at this site.
To conclude, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision on the major challenges related to the environment, by 2020 and beyond.
That is the entire purpose of launching a seventh environmental action program by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new sources of funding.
This program must ensure consistency and coordination between the European Union’s environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, land use planning, and urban policies, naturally.
Despite the economic crisis that is undermining the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate domain.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, particularly with regard to the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote ecodesign, recycling, but also environmental product labeling in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental pedagogy essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a policy programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also for entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union’s environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a shackle.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is subject to today, the Union must reform its system of generalized preferences.
As with any compromise, this one does not deviate from the norm.
While satisfying from a purely commercial perspective, it is far from perfect. We must bear in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
In developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries.
That does not appear entirely sustainable at first glance.
To this end, the Commission nevertheless developed a strictly accounting perspective based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
One can clearly see the limitation of this approach.
Leaving many developing, middle-income countries, whose economies are undiversified and vulnerable to climate shocks.
The agreement reached with the Council does not address this issue, and that is why I urge my colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be submitted on this text.
Sir Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is not new, unfortunately.

It is, in my view, a crucial question, and that is why I have already not only put several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal treatment and access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
Mr. President, I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response that public consultations do not purport to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and viewpoints may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
This is not an answer.
I question the criteria that would allow for the measurement of an overrepresentation of the European population.
