If written consultations are not overrepresented due solely to availability in English, for example, they fail to achieve their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to maintain written consultations as a foundation for the European Commission’s legislative proposals, we must guarantee a democratic, transparent, and equitable system for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission conducts written consultations, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to integrate into the analysis excessively short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately primarily accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to grant the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be compelled by Brussels’ technocrats to implement budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial equilibrium.
This enhanced monitoring is referred to as guardianship.
States will be penalized, fined, essentially sanctioned; financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even though some amendments aim to prevent austerity measures alone through growth initiatives, your proposals are merely intended to help people swallow the bitter pill.
Growth, as you and I know, is not decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we permanently lose our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the tactics of the Chinese thief, the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finished constituting itself, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr. President, without diminishing the importance of the economic choices we must assume, you will permit me to emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate.
Over recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain European leaders, or those who consider themselves to be such.
As everyone continues to advocate for economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies finally worthy of the name, and as this demand even appears as a condition
a near equivalent of the euro zone's survival, and now that they are comfortably settled in, these clever M. Croix are keen to disparage the balanced recommendations emanating from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to turn public opinion against these Brussels apparatchiks, as has been said.
This irresponsible attitude could be laughable were we not in such a tragic situation.
I tell you plainly, our debates concerning stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances, or the efforts to be undertaken in terms of growth are indeed destined to
failure if the past’s missteps regarding debt and public deficits do not cease and if the governments of the Member States persist in their misguided course.
We are playing with fire at the moment.
European discipline must apply to everyone, without exception, even for the Grand Duché of Luxembourg.
It requires a minimum of courage, and our public opinions are ready for it, far more so than some of their leaders would believe.
A final word to Ms. Goulard, otherwise I will have to show her the blue card—I will say, to conclude, to Ms. Goulard, in Redemption, there are redemptions.

Mr. President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission and, in particular, your own, Commissioner, for having tirelessly placed the recovery and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

You reminded me, Commissioner, that for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the single market, to identify the challenges and sectors for which more single market integration is needed—more single market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also ultimately signaled the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the single market, the twelve drivers of growth.
Rather than constantly seeking to invent new instruments of growth, we would be well-advised to work with the toolkit we already possess.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution to be submitted tomorrow for a vote by our assembly to send a strong political message to the Member States regarding greater speed and efficiency in the transposition of directives already adopted.

He has adopted greater mobilization and engagement on newly opened construction sites. I will cite only one example: the reinforcement of worker mobility, greater ease of circulation, and smoother traffic flow.
We shall welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political resolve and the ability to put pressure on Member States.
We experienced the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the scandal of breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, the shortcomings of European health safety.
This scandal involving breast implants, these fourteen years of fraud, 1996-2010, unpunished.
These are 500 prostheses used worldwide, 8 implant removals, 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
It’s now 3 complaints filed; this figure is alarming, shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the FDA, Mr. Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions for prosthesis failure filed in Great Britain and France, in particular, how could the national and European agencies have failed to detect such a fraud?
This tragedy immediately led us to reflect on an improvement to the European system for the control of medical devices, as you have just explained.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today capable of avoiding scandal, but it is a new system that must be built.
It is announced for the autumn, as you indicated, this new legislation.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am, of course, very satisfied.
But, Mr. Commissioner, you appear to be willing to take into account a significant portion of our concerns, as dictated by this resolution.
So, why make an unacceptable exception for so many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why would one not want the creation of a market authorization for class 3 medical devices, those posing the highest risk?
Mr. Commissioner Dalli, could you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of over 2.5%, while industrialists are lowering prices.
In Italy, in Germany, in England, and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This clearly indicates that prices are linked to the volume of production and that production volumes and, simultaneously, prices must be organized.
At the same time, today, producers are experiencing an increase of over 44% in plant proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the necessity, here, of ensuring that value is distributed among producers and that farmers are not victims of businesses and large-scale retail.

I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the questioning of production control, but at the same time I say very clearly that Member States must get their own houses in order, because there are countries that have respected the rules of quotas and others that have not.
That, too, is what led to these quotas being challenged.
There is therefore a dual responsibility for the Commission and the Member States.
Gentlemen, esteemed colleagues, a single European railway network – now that is a commendable European integration policy.
Here is a fine policy wherein European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often decried because of its breakdowns, Europe, at last, with this directive, shows the way towards a major policy of sustainable transport and opens the field for a significant railway investment policy for employment.

Mr. President, I welcome the key measures taken in the organization of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, and the creation of a five-year multiannual investment framework, thereby stipulating financing commitments of

rail infrastructure, but I also welcomed the implementation of transparency in financial flows between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder regarding non-discriminatory access to certain

services and, finally, I welcomed the confirmation sought by Members of the European Parliament of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front, for example, the absence of reference to minimum service requirements as well as full unbundling between the CNR game and the operator.

But allow me to mention a requirement that we must cease to consider, particularly from the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the sole strategic horizon for the development of a single railway area, and instead decide upon an integrated European investment strategy conducive to employment in Europe.
Also, I would like, to conclude, to pose a question to you, Commissioner Kallas.
Three days ago, following the European Council of June 28th and 29th, and after the validation of a growth pact worth €120 billion to revitalize the European economy.
And notably through investment in infrastructure. Could you indicate to us, Mr. Commissioner, what sum the European railway sector is likely to benefit from within the framework of this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address a question this evening that is, admittedly, peripheral but extremely important in relation to this matter.
These are the remarks made by the Commissioner, Mr. De Gucht, in the Committee on International Trade on Wednesday, June 20th.
I quote: if you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me say that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We committed ourselves to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

justice. Not only do these remarks seem to disregard the treaties, but more importantly, and this is what I want to denounce, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens we represent.

Mr. President, at this hour, many things have been said.
Sir Commissioner, as for myself, I would like to thank you most warmly.
Thanks to your persistence, your procedural tactics, you allow us to demonstrate the importance of the European Parliament as a legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for prompting hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that European elected officials are representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who continue to follow us today.

Mr. President, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
It is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like, tomorrow, to also thank you for assuming your responsibility, your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee on the report by Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to recall that when a nation wishes to sanction a country practicing unsustainable fishing, it must take its level of development into consideration.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence for development, it is crucial, in my view, that measures adopted in the area of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher’s draft report reiterates this important principle for our development committee by stipulating that measures must not be unwarranted or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives, and to ensure that the level of development and the vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of the stocks, as claimed by environmental organizations and the European Commission, encompassing all categories of fishing.

It is, of course, essential to preserve fish stocks, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to earn a living from their activity and to preserve the economic fabric, the dynamism, and the cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Alternatively, the European executive’s main measures will, once again, move in the direction of reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I recall that the French fleet has decreased by over 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the establishment of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration within the sector, or even a total ban on discharges, which professionals consider to be unrealistic.
This reform project will likely suit the industrial fleet, but in its current form, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

of the stabilization mechanism, no possibility offered to our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as potentially constituting unfair advantageous practices.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Goerens for his excellent report.
We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world’s total of official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline of 2015 approaches, even if some objectives seem
affected, we must ask ourselves how to improve our assistance, how to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must rest on firm commitments that are precise, measurable, and scheduled for the short and medium term.
The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging nations, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems concerning environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from bodies that function effectively at the decision-making level, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not merely charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for ourselves.
It is enough to look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries: China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also provide an opportunity to better account for the geostrategic shifts of recent years, as the emerging nations of today were, until recently, still developing countries.
From now on, as an indispensable economic power, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as simple financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and with those from the economic and social committee and the regional committee in requesting that 2015 be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my opinion, raises numerous questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid be based on the mechanical application of the sole criterion of per capita wealth.
As Ms. Ashton recalled, these issues are not solely of an accounting nature, but merit a genuine political debate regarding the definition of our priorities in international cooperation.
Furthermore, in my view, this differentiated approach does not align with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us acknowledge the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment the Berlin Wall was falling.

Despite this, despite all the advancements we have observed since the beginning of our debate, it must be acknowledged that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would therefore like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to indicate to us how we will together construct a more equitable Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues, which are at the heart of the economic and social crisis, as we unfortunately know it: tax harmonization, public services.
protectors, minimum wage in Europe, establishment of strengthened cooperation, job creators, facilitate cross-border cooperation and develop a policy of fair exchange.
These are, I believe, the challenges that lie before us twenty years later.
I rely on you, Commissioner, to ensure that we jointly pursue this fine policy of European construction.

Mr. President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have closely examined the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We debated this report, which is also connected to our discussion on the twenty years of the single market.
Twenty years ago, the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was already supposed to be able to fully operate within our living space, exchange area, and internal market.

I was particularly interested to note that, among the precautions expressed by our European fellow citizens, the core of professional qualifications features prominently, and that we truly must be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our citizens expect to genuinely enable, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their credentials, their skills, and their professional qualifications—procedures that are truly faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a genuine challenge.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the PPE group on this subject, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to genuinely address this major challenge of mobility.

For greater mobility, for a greater Europe, that is what our citizens are asking for.
I thank you.
Mr. President, the Committee on Petitions has this year acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearings of European citizens' initiatives.
It is for me the strong signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a Commission to which they could turn in the event of a violation of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I wish that the Committee on Petitions could thus be increasingly regarded as the preferred interlocutor of citizens with the European Parliament.
This consideration problem is also reflected in the results of the petitions committee's decisions.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal complexities on which we wish to take a stance, but when the issues are European,
Even if solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

Mr. President, I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights extend beyond national borders, those of Germany, for instance.
Despite the blatant difficulties faced by many parents of children born of binational unions, we remain, in Parliament, powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, particularly from Germany, which submits a great many petitions on the model of the French Defender of Rights, has had no effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a conciliatory solution, a problematic European issue, and a national solution.
In many cases, European law appears unable to meet the expectations of citizens.
